What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is, in that world Abundance, called corruption, or ignorance, or great enemy, or sharp blade, or taste of destruction or revenge, or not one’s own thing, or bad guidance, or increasing darkness, or ruining goodness. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is, in that world Abundance, called great meaning, or benefit, or goal of goals, or infinity, or what should be seen, or detachment from discrimination, or supreme pacification, or constant equanimity, or worthy of living together, or nonfabrication. What is called the holy truth of the path to extinction of suffering is, in that world Abundance, called able to burn up, or the highest class, or certitude, or unbreakable, or profound techniques, or emancipation, or not mean or base, or mastery, or essence of liberation, or capable of setting free. In that world Abundance there are four quadrillion such names to explain the tour holy truths, to cause sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang 'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di na sdug bsngal 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la 'jig rten gyi khams rdul bsal ba na 'gyod pa zhes bya'o/ / kun spyod pa zhes bya'o/ / gcig la gcig ces bya'o/ / kun tu 'gro ba zhes bya'o/ / ro gcig pa zhes bya'o/ / chos ma yin pa zhes bya'o/ / kun gzhi dang mngon sum zhes bya'o/ / log pa la gzhol ba zhes bya'o/ / log par lta ba zhes bya'o/ / grangs med pa zhes bya'o/ / dgra'i dpung zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal kun 'byung ba 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams rdul bsal ba na 'dod chags pa zhes bya'o/ / smra ba zhes bya'o/ / mi dkar ba zhes bya'o/ / gzhi las skyes pa zhes bya'o/ / bzung ba zhes bya'o/ / sdig pa'i kha ba zhes bya'o/ / lhag pa zhes bya'o/ / khur zhes bya'o/ / skyed pa zhes bya'o/ / sra ba zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog pa 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de yang 'jig rten gyi khams rdul med pa na mi mnyam pa zhes bya'o/ / bral ba zhes bya'o/ / dri ma med pa zhes bya'o/ / rtsa ba dang bral ba zhes bya'o/ / ldan pa zhes bya'o/ / sgrim pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / bag la nyal ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / 'phags pa zhes bya'o/ / phyi ma zhes bya'o/ / dgra bcom pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /gang sdug bsngal 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams rdul bsal ba na dngos po'i snying po zhes bya'o/ / skal pa sbyor ba zhes bya'o/ / grol ba'i don gyi rtsa ba zhes bya'o/ / rang bzhin du gyur pa zhes bya'o/ / mi smad pa zhes bya'o/ / mchog tu rnam par dag pa zhes bya'o/ / srid pa'i mtha' ma zhes bya'o/ / spa ba'i snying po zhes bya'o/ / mthar thug par byed pa zhes bya'o/ / yongs su rtog pa dag pa zhes bya ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de ltar de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams rdul bsal ba na 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo; ;

“What is, in this world Endurance, called the holy truth of suffering, is, in the world Undefiled, also called regret, or dependency, or aggravation, or dwelling within walls, or one flavor, or untruth, or living at home, or abode of deluded attachment, or false views, or innumerable. What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is, in the world Undefiled, also called no real thing, or only having words, or not pure, or place of birth, or grasping, or baseness, or increase, or heavy burden, or producer, or roughness. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is, in the world Undefiled, also called incomparable, or thoroughly cleared, or removal of defilement, or supreme faculties, or harmony, or independence, or extinction of confusion, or most excellent, or the ultimate, or breaking the seal. What is called the holy truth of the path to the extinction of suffering is, in that world Undefiled, called something indestructible, or the part of appropriate means, or the basis of liberation, or reality of basic nature, or the blameless, or the most pure, or the boundary of all existences, or maintaining what is received complete, or producing the ultimate, or pure discernment. In the world Undefiled there are four quadrillion such names to explain the four holy truths, to cause all sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang 'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di na sdug bsngal 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la 'jig rten gyi khams rnam par byung ba na 'dod chags kyis rgyas pa zhes bya'o/ / gtum pa'i rtsa ba zhes bya'o/ / rgya mtsho'i yan lag ces bya'o/ / yang dag pa las 'das pa'i sbyor ba zhes bya'o/ / skal pa med pa'i rtsa ba zhes bya'o/ / 'phro ba zhes bya'o/ / skye zhing 'jig pa zhes bya'o/ / sgrib pa zhes bya'o/ / ral gri'i dngo zhes bya'o/ / tshal stug po zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal pa'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal kun 'byung ba 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de yang 'jig rten gyi khams rnam par byung ba na nor bu sbyin pa zhes bya'o/ / 'dud par byed pa zhes bya'o/ / mi zad pa zhes bya'o/ / skal pa zhes bya'o/ / chags pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / seng+ge zhes bya'o/ / dngos po len pa zhes bya'o/ / 'brel ba zhes bya'o/ / snod ces bya'o/ / g.yo ba zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog pa 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de yang 'jig rten gyi khams rnam par byung ba na mtshams bral ba zhes bya'o/ / phye ba zhes bya'o/ / yi ge med pa zhes bya'o/ / sbyor ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / mthong ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / bya ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / nye bar bsgrubs pa zhes bya'o/ / sred pa zhes bya'o/ / gzhol ba zhes bya'o/ / skyed pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la 'jig rten gyi khams rnam par byung ba na zhi bar byed pa rjod pa zhes bya'o/ / khyab par 'gro ba zhes bya'o/ / mngon du bya ba la sbyor ba zhes bya'o/ / bde bar 'gro ba zhes bya'o/ / tshe tshad med pa zhes bya'o/ / shin tu bsgoms pas mthar phyin pa zhes bya'o/ / lam gyi dam pa zhes bya'o/ / thob par dka' ba'i yan lag ces bya'o/ / pha rol gyi mtshams zhes bya'o/ / brgal dka' ba zhes bya ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams rnam par byung ba na 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ /

“What is, in this world Endurance, called the holy truth of suffering, is, in the world Rich Pleasure, also called the place of emotional attachment, or root of danger and harm, or the sectors of the ocean of existence, or made by accumulation, or discriminating senses, or aggravation, or origination and destruction, or hindrance, or base of sword blades, or made of sets. What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is, in the world Rich Pleasure, called detestable, or names, or endless, or different sets, or not to be loved, or able to grab and bite, or crude things, or emotional attachment, or receptacle, or stirring. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is, in that world Rich Pleasure, called end of continuation, or revelation, or no label, or nothing to practice, or no object of vision, or nondoing, or extinction, or already burnt out, or casting off the heavy burden, or purged. What is called the holy truth of the path to extinction of suffering is, in that world Rich Pleasure, called serene action, or emancipating action, or diligent practice and experience, or gone to tranquility, or infinite life, or comprehensive knowledge, or the ultimate path, or difficult to practice, or reaching the other shore, or invincible. In the world Rich Pleasure there are four quadrillion such names to explain the four holy truths, to cause all sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang 'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di na sdug bsngal 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de yang 'jig rten gyi khams 'pho bar byed pa na 'phrog par byed pa zhes bya'o/ / smon pa'i bshes gnyen zhes bya'o/ / mi brtan zhing 'jig pa zhes bya'o/ / brjod pa sna tshogs zhes bya'o/ / nyam nga bas 'tsho ba zhes bya'o/ / don 'dul ba zhes bya'o/ / khur 'dor ba zhes bya'o/ / rtsa ba zab pa zhes bya'o/ / de bzhin sems pa zhes bya'o/ / nam mkha'i rtsa ba zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal kun 'byung ba 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de yang 'jig rten gyi khams 'pho bar byed pa na sred par byed pa zhes bya'o/ / shin tu sbyor ba zhes bya'o/ / nyes pas skyon can du gyur pa zhes bya'o/ / rlabs zhes bya'o/ / 'dzin pa zhes bya'o/ / 'du shes can zhes bya'o; ; 'bras bu la gnas pa zhes bya'o/ / brjod du mi rung ba zhes bya'o/ / tha dad pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / rab tu 'jug pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog pa 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de yang 'jig rten gyi khams 'pho bar byed pa na bzlog pa zhes bya'o/ / smra ba dang bral ba zhes bya'o/ / sgrub pa zhes bya'o/ / dga' ba zhes bya'o/ / 'jigs pa bsal ba zhes bya'o/ / shin tu byung ba zhes bya'o/ / gti mug med pa zhes bya'o/ / nub pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / 'phags pa zhes bya'o; ;
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de yang 'jig rten gyi khams 'pho bar byed pa na brjod du med pa zhes bya'o/ / tshul nyams pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / rnam par rig pa'i lam zhes bya'o/ / bsngo ba dge ba zhes bya'o/ / rgya chen po la mkhas pa zhes bya'o/ / rnam par phye ba'i tshul zhes bya'o/ / nam mkha'i rang bzhin zhes bya'o/ / zil par gyur ba zhes bya'o/ / ye shes kyi bdag po zhes bya'o/ / don yongs su shes pa zhes bya ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de ltar de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams 'pho bar byed pa na 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ /

“What is in this world Endurance, called the holy truth of suffering, is, in the world Inclusion, also called able to plunder and usurp, or not a good friend, or full of fear, or various fancies, or the nature of hell, or untruth, or the burden of covetousness, or roots of deep gravity, or changing with moods, or fundamental vanity. What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is called, in that world Inclusion, greedy attachment, or wrong accomplishment, or the evil of excess, or nothing that can be explained, or nothing that can be apprehended, or continuous revolving in circles. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is, in the world Inclusion, called nonregression, or beyond speech, or formlessness, or enjoyable, or stability, or supreme wonder, or freedom from folly, or extinction, or detachment from evil, or escape. What is called the holy truth of the path to extinction of suffering is, in the world Inclusion, called beyond words, or noncontention, or teaching and guidance, or good dedication, or great skill, or a variety of techniques, or spacelike, or serene action, or supreme knowledge, or ability to understand truth. In the world Inclusion there are four quadrillion such names to explain the four holy truths, to cause sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang 'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di nyid na sdug bsngal 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams phan pa na khur tsa ba'i khur zhes bya'o/ / snying po med pa zhes bya'o/ / rkun po lta bu zhes bya'o/ / rga shi zhes bya'o/ / chags pa'i rang bzhin zhes bya'o/ / shin tu mched pa zhes bya'o/ / ngal bar byed pa zhes bya'o/ / ngom zum gnag pa zhes bya'o/ / kun tu 'phel ba zhes bya'o/ / ral gri dang 'dra ba zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal kun 'byung ba 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la yang 'jig rten gyi khams phan pa na 'jig pa zhes bya'o/ / 'khrugs pa zhes bya'o/ / bskyod pa zhes bya'o/ / nyam chung ba zhes bya'o/ / 'phrog pa zhes bya'o/ / bral ba zhes bya'o/ / mi ldan pa zhes bya'o/ / 'thab mor gyur pa zhes bya'o/ / rtsod par gyur pa zhes bya'o/ / gnas su gyur pa zhes bya'o; ;
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog pa 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams phan pa na kun spyod pa zhes bya'o/ / yang dag pa zhes bya'o; ; zhum pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / yan lag g.yogs pa zhes bya'o/ / smad pa spangs pa zhes bya'o/ / rjes su mthun pa zhes bya'o/ / gzhir 'gro ba zhes bya'o/ / yan lag spangs pa zhes bya'o/ / tha dad pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / glags med pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la yang 'jig rten gyi khams phan pa na snang ba rjod pa zhes bya'o/ / thams cad kyi rgya zhes bya'o/ / bsam gtan gyi gter zhes bya'o/ / snang ba yod pa zhes bya'o/ / phyir mi ldog pa'i chos can zhes bya'o/ / dngos po zad pa zhes bya'o/ / lam yangs pa zhes bya'o/ / dul ba'i rang bzhin zhes bya'o/ / dge ba yod pa zhes bya'o/ / rtsa ba rgyu ba med pa zhes bya ba ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de ltar de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams phan pa na 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ /

“What is, in this world Endurance, called the holy truth of suffering, is, in the world Beneficial, also called the heavy burden, or instability, or like a robber, or aging and death, or made of craving, or transmigration, or fatigue, or bad condition, or growth, or the sharp blade. What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is, in the world Beneficial, called decay, or confusion, or regression, or powerlessness, or loss, or opposition, or disharmony, or doing, or grasping, or wishing. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is, in the world Beneficial, also called escape from prison, or real truth, or freedom from troubles, or protection, or detachment from ill, or docility, or the fundamental, or abandoning the cause, or nonstriving, or noncontinuation. What is called the holy truth of the path to the extinction of suffering is, in that world Beneficial, also called arriving at nonexistence, or the seal of the totality, or the treasury of meditation, or attainment of light, or the nonregressive state, or ability to put an end to being, or the wide great road, or ability to tame, or having peace and security, or nonroutinized faculties. In the world Beneficial there are four quadrillion such names to explain the four holy truths, to cause sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang 'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di na sdug bsngal 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la yang 'jig rten gyi khams kun tu 'gro ba na bsam pa thibs po zhes bya'o/ / gnas sna tshogs su bkram pa zhes bya'o/ / skye gnas su skyed pa zhes bya'o/ / rim pas 'dug pa zhes bya'o/ / ngo tsha med pa zhes bya'o/ / shes par bya ba'i rtsa ba zhes bya'o/ / 'ga' 'ga'i ro zhes bya'o; ; rtsig pa zhes bya'o/ / rtag tu 'jig pa zhes bya'o/ / mgal me'i rang bzhin zhes bya'o/ / rtsa ba'i sgo zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal kun 'byung 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams kun tu 'gro ba na shin tu g.yo ba zhes bya'o/ / rig pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / blo gros dang ring ba zhes bya'o/ / phongs par 'gyur ba zhes bya'o/ / 'jig pa zhes bya'o/ / kun tu 'dren pa zhes bya'o/ / nye bar sgrub pa zhes bya'o/ / rten du gyur pa zhes bya'o/ / dngos po'i bdag po zhes bya'o/ / mtshams sbyor ba zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog pa 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams kun tu 'gro ba na ngoms pa zhes bya'o/ / bdud rtsi zhes bya'o/ / rgyu ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / rang gi med pa zhes bya'o/ / rtog pa byang ba zhes bya'o/ / yang dag par gzhol ba zhes bya'o/ / rgyu ba dang bral ba zhes bya'o/ / mched pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / lam med pa zhes bya'o/ / mi gnyis pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /gang sdug bsngal 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la yang 'jig rten gyi khams kun tu 'gro ba na snang bar byed pa zhes bya'o/ / bstan pa rgya mtsho zhes bya'o/ / don rnam par gdon mi za ba zhes bya'o/ / chos dang phrad pa zhes bya'o/ / 'khor ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / 'brel ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / lam rgya chen po zhes bya'o/ / yang dag par phyin par 'gro ba zhes bya'o/ / sbyor ba dag pa zhes bya'o/ / mthong ba'i bdag po zhes bya ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de ltar de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams kun tu 'gro ba na 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ /

“What is, in this world Endurance, called the holy truth of suffering, is, in the world Rarefied, also called dangerous desires, or place of bondage, or misguided action, or receptivity, or shamelessness, or rooted in greed, or the ever-flowing river, or constant disintegration, or of the nature of torch fire, or full of stress and anxiety. What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is, in that world, called broad ground, or tendency, or distance from wisdom, or obstruction, or fear, or laxity, or taking in, or attachment, or ignorance being master of the house, or continuous bonds. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is, in that world, also called fulfillment, or immortality, or selflessness, or absence of inherent nature, or end of discrimination, or abode of peace and happiness, or infinitude, or cutting off transmigration, or cutting off compulsive mental activity, or nonduality. What is called the holy truth of the path to extinction of suffering is, in that world, also called great light, or ocean of explanation, or analyzing meaning, or the way of harmony, or freedom from attachment, or breaking the continuum, or the broad highway, or the basis of impartiality, or pure methods, or supreme insight. In that world Rarefied are four quadrillion such names to explain the four holy truths, to cause sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di na sdug bsngal 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams yongs su dga' ba na skye bar byed pa zhes bya'o/ / rnam par sgrub pa zhes bya'o/ / chags shing zhen pa zhes bya'o/ / khur khyer ba zhes bya'o/ / mi sdug pa'i rnam pa zhes bya'o/ / nad thibs po zhes bya'o/ / sdig pa byed pa zhes bya'o// sdug bsngal bar byed pa'i rang bzhin ces bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag / gang sdug bsngal kun 'byung ba 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams yongs su dga' ba na gzhir gyur pa zhes bya'o/ / sbyor ba dang ldan pa zhes bya'o/ / tshod las 'das pa zhes bya'o/ / chos 'phel ba zhes bya'o/ / rtog pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / sdud pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / sdud par byed pa zhes bya'o/ / lang du red pa zhes bya'o/ / chos kyi gzhi zhes bya'o/ / lta ba chung ba zhes bya'o/ / mthong ba chung ba zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /gang sdug bsngal 'gog pa 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la yang 'jig rten gyi khams yongs su dga' ba na gnas zhig pa zhes bya'o/ / rmongs pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / yang dag pa zhes bya'o/ / des shin tu rtog pa zhes bya'o/ / dge bar byed pa zhes bya'o/ / skyon med pa zhes bya'o/ / 'khor ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / mtshan nyid med pa zhes bya'o/ / bdag nyid rtogs pa zhes bya'o/ / ma skyes pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /sdug bsngal 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la yang 'jig rten gyi khams yongs su dga' ba na sa mtshams nye bar gyur pa zhes bya'o/ / sel ba dang 'grogs pa zhes bya'o/ / skal pa mi mnyam pa'i don can ces bya'o/ / rang bzhin yangs pa zhes bya'o/ / yongs su rtog pa zad pa zhes bya'o/ / byin gyi rlabs kyi lam zhes bya'o/ / tshogs kyi tshul zhes bya'o/ / dran pa dang bral zhes bya'o/ / rtag pa'i lam zhes bya'o/ / grol ba sgrub pa zhes bya ste/
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ltar de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams yongs su dga' ba na 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ /

“What is, in this world Endurance, called the holy truth of suffering, is, in the world Joy, called continuous revolving, or birth, or loss of benefit, or habitual attachment, or the heavy load, or discrimination, or inward danger, or gathering, or wrong abode, or of the nature of misery and affliction. What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is, in that world, also called the ground, or conveniences, or wrong timing, or untruth, or bottomless, or possessiveness, or departure from morality, or afflictions, or narrow views, or accumulation of defilement. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is, in that world, called destroying dependency, or not indulging, or truth, or equality, or purity, or freedom from sickness, or undistorted, or formless, or free, or birthless. What is called the holy truth of the path to extinction of suffering is, in that world, called entering the supreme realm, or cutting off accumulation, or transcending comparison, or vast nature, or end of discrimination, or the path of spiritual power, or multitude of appropriate techniques, or practice of right mindfulness, or the ever quiet road, or embracing liberation. In that world Joy there are four quadrillion such names to explain the four holy truths, to cause beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang 'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di na sdug bsngal 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams mi che ba na 'tshogs pa zhes bya'o/ / rdza ma lta bu zhes bya'o/ / nad dang mnyam pa zhes bya'o/ / lus la yod pa zhes bya'o/ / rab tu 'phel ba zhes bya'o/ / gsog pa'i sgo zhes bya'o// sdug bsngal gyi skyon can zhes bya'o/ / brtag par bya ba zhes bya'o/ / rang la gzhog pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / 'gro zhing 'ong ba zhes bya'o; /kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal kun 'byung ba 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la yang 'jig rten gyi khams mi che ba na 'tshe ba zhes bya'o/ / mdud par 'dzin pa zhes bya'o/ / rab tu sbyor ba zhes bya'o/ / tshor ba'i yan lag ces bya'o/ / a.a na sems pa zhes bya'o/ / rab rab byed pa zhes bya'o/ / 'dud par byed pa zhes bya'o/ / rnam par bral ba zhes bya'o/ / shin tu gdung ba zhes bya'o/ / kyi hud na zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog pa 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams mi che ba na gsog pa med pa zhes bya'o/ / g.yo ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / skyon med pa zhes bya'o/ / ma nyams pa zhes bya'o/ / 'grogs ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / tshad med pa zhes bya'o/ / yangs pa zhes bya'o/ / sangs rgyas kyi yan lag ces bya'o/ / 'dod chags dang bral ba zhes bya'o/ / ma chags pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgya ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la yang 'jig rten gyi khams mi che ba na bstan pa'i spyod yul zhes bya'o/ / 'dod chags dang bral ba'i sa mtshams zhes bya'o/ / bden pa la thug pa zhes bya'o/ / don rab tu chud pa zhes bya'o/ / rang bzhin la gtugs pa zhes bya'o/ / lta ba yongs su dag pa zhes bya'o/ / dran pas sgrub pa zhes bya'o/ / 'gro bas sdud pa zhes bya'o/ / skyob pa'i sa mtshams zhes bya'o/ / 'khrug pa med par 'gro ba zhes bya ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de ltar de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams mi che ba na 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams la ming bye ba brgya phrag bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ /

“What is, in this world Endurance, called the holy truth of suffering, is, in the world Door Bolt, also called decaying form, or like a broken vessel, or the product of ego, or embodiment of various tendencies, or numerous routines, or the gate of the multitude of ills, or inherent pain, or that which should be abandoned, or flavorlessness, or coming and going. What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is in that world called activity, or the poison of anger, or conglomeration, or sensation, or selfishness, or mixed poison, or empty names, or opposition, or imitation, or astonishment. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is in that world called no accumulation, or ungraspable, or wonder medicine, or incorruptible, or nonattachment, or immeasurable, or vast, or the sphere of awakening, or freedom from addiction, or absence of obstruction. What is called the holy truth of the path to extinction of suffering is in that world called peaceful action, or detachment from craving, or ultimate reality, or entry into truth, or the essential ultimate, or manifestation of purity, or concentration, or heading for liberation, or salvation, or supreme action. In that world Door Bolt there are four quadrillion such names to express the four holy truths, to cause sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang 'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di na sdug bsngal 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams dbyangs sgrog pa na bsam pa nub pa zhes bya'o/ / shin tu 'gro ba zhes bya'o/ / yan lag gnas pa zhes bya'o/ / g.yo sgyu che ba zhes bya'o/ / 'brel pa zhes bya'o/ / 'dod pa 'byung ba zhes bya'o/ / myang du mi rung ba zhes bya'o/ / skye gnas ma rung ba zhes bya'o/ / nye bar 'gro ba zhes bya'o/ / dngo skam pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal kun 'byung ba 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams dbyangs sgrog pa na gdul ba'i gzhi zhes bya'o/ / sems kyi tshul zhes bya'o/ / bcings pa dang ldan pa zhes bya'o/ / rjes su dran pa zhes bya'o/ / nges par rtog pa ma yin pa zhes bya'o/ / rnal 'byor dang mi mthun pa zhes bya'o/ / brtag par bya ba zhes bya'o/ / sgo zhes bya'o/ / rtogs par bya ba zhes bya'o/ / bsgribs pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal pa'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog pa 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams dbyangs sgrog pa na gnas med pa zhes bya'o/ / sbyin sreg gi dam pa zhes bya'o/ / phyir log pa zhes bya'o/ / mya ngan dang bral ba zhes bya'o/ / kun tu song ba zhes bya'o/ / chen po zhes bya'o/ / du ba med pa zhes bya'o/ / mi zad pa zhes bya'o/ / yangs pa zhes bya'o/ / shin tu mchod pa zhes bya'o/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ gang sdug bsngal 'gog par 'gro ba'i lam 'phags pa'i bden pa zhes bya ba de la'ang 'jig rten gyi khams dbyangs sgrog pa na mthong bas mthong ba zhes bya'o/ / spang ba'i don ces bya'o/ / rnam par sgom pa'i rgya zhes bya'o/ / mtshan nyid la 'jug pa zhes bya'o/ / rnyed par dka' ba zhes bya'o/ / de ma thag pa'i don ces bya'o/ / mkhas pas brtag pa zhes bya'o/ / 'grogs pa'i don ces bya'o/ / mi g.yo ba la mngon du gyur ba zhes bya'o/ / khyad par gyi don ces bya ste/ kye rgyal ba'i sras dag /de ltar de dag la sogs pa 'jig rten gyi khams dbyangs sgrog pa na 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ /

“What is, in this world Endurance, called the holy truth of suffering, is, in the world Shaking Sound, also called hidden sickness, or the mundane, or the dwelling place, or conceit, or the nature of habitual attachment, or the torrent, or unenjoyable, or hypocrisy, or the evanescent, or difficult to control. What is called the holy truth of the accumulation of suffering is in that world called that which must be controlled, or mental tendencies, or that which binds, or arising in every thought, or extending to the future, or combination, or discrimination, or the gateway, or blown by the wind, or concealment. What is called the holy truth of the extinction of suffering is in that world called no reliance, or ungraspable, or returning, or freedom from conflict or small, or great, or pure, or inexhaustible, or broad, or priceless. What is called the holy truth of the path to extinction of suffering is in that world called analytic observation, or ability to destroy the enemy, or seal of knowledge, or ability to enter the essence, or unopposable, or limitless meaning, or able to enter knowledge, or the path of harmony, or eternal imperturbability, or the highest truth. In that world Shaking Sound there are four quadrillion such names to explain the four holy truths, to cause sentient beings to be harmonized and pacified according to their mentalities.

kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ 'jig rten gyi khams mi mjed 'di na ji ltar 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams yongs su bstan pa yod pa de bzhin du shar phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba brgya stong tshad med pa/ dpag tu med pa/ grangs med pa; bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ mtshungs pa med pa/ kun tu mtha' yas pa/ mu med pa/ sa mtshams med pa/ brjod du med pa/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa/ nam mkha'i dbyings kyi mthas gtugs pa dag na yang 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams yongs su bstan pa yod do/ / 'jig rten gyi khams re re na yang 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ / shar phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams na ji lta ba de bzhin du lho phyogs dang / de bzhin du nub phyogs dang / de bzhin du byang phyogs dang / de bzhin du byang shar gyi phyogs mtshams dang; de bzhin du shar lho'i phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du lho nub kyi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du nub byang gi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du 'og gi phyogs dang / de bzhin du steng gi phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong tshad med pa/ grangs med pa/ bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ mtshungs pa med pa/ kun tu mtha' yas pa/ mu med pa/ sa mtshams med pa/ gzhal du med pa/ brjod du med pa/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa/ nam mkha'i dbyings kyi mthas gtugs pa dag na yang 'phags pa'i bden pa yongs su bstan pa yod do/ / 'jig rten gyi khams re re na yang 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams kyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ / 'jig rten gyi khams gcig na ji lta ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad shar phyogs nas steng gi phyogs zhes bya ba nas phyogs bcu ma lus pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi bar dag na yang 'phags pa'i bden pa rnams yongs su bstan pa yod do/ / 'jig rten gyi khams re re na yang sdug bsngal gyi ming bye ba brgya stong phrag bzhi bcu bzhi bcu yod de/ de dag gis sems can rnams bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du 'dul lo/ / kun 'byung ba'i bden pa'i ming dang / 'gog pa'i bden pa'i ming dang / lam gyi bden pa'i ming dag kyang de bzhin no/ /

“Just as in this world Endurance there are four quadrillion names to express the four holy truths, so in all the worlds to the east—hundreds of thousands of billions, countlessly, innumerably, boundlessly, imcomparably, incalculably, unspeakably, inconceivably, immeasurably, inexplicably many worlds, in each there are an equal number of names to express the four holy truths, to cause the sentient beings there to all be harmonized and pacified in accordance with their mentalities. And just as this is so of the worlds to the east, so it is with all the infinite worlds in the ten directions.”
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ 'phags pa'i bden pa'i le'u zhes bya ba ste/ bcu gsum pa'o// //
[14. de bzhin gshegs pa'i 'od zer las rnam par sangs rgyas pa'i le'u]
BOOK NINE. Awakening by Light

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs kyi mthil gnyis nas 'od zer bye ba phrag brgya bkye ste/ stong gsum gyi stong chen po'i 'jig rten gyi khams 'di snang bar byas nas 'dzam bu'i gling bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / shar gyi lus 'phags gling bye ba phrag brgya dang / nub kyi ba lang spyod bye ba phrag brgya dang / byang gi sgra mi snyan bye ba phrag brgya dang / rgya mtsho chen po bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / 'khor yug rdo rje'i ri bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / byang chub sems dpa' skye ba bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / mngon par 'byung ba bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / de bzhin gshegs pa rnam par 'tshang rgya ba bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / de bzhin gshegs pa yongs su mya ngan las 'da' pa bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / ri rab ri'i rgyal po bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / rgyal po chen po bzhi'i khams kyi lha'i ris bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / sum cu rtsa gsum gyi lha'i ris bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / mtshe ma'i lha'i ris bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / dga' ldan gyi lha'i ris bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / 'phrul dga'i lha'i ris bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / gzhan 'phrul dbang byed kyi lha'i ris bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / tshangs pa'i 'jig rten bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / gya nom snang ba bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / dge rgyas bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / 'bras bu chen po bye ba phrag brgya bstan to/ / 'og min bye ba phrag brgya bstan te/ 'jig rten gyi khams 'di'i khongs su gang ci yang rung ste gtogs par gyur pa de dag thams cad ril gyis bstan to/ /

THEN THE BUDDHA, from beneath the wheel-marks on his feet, emitted a hundred billion light beams, illuminating this billion-world universe, with its four hundred billion continents, hundred billion oceans, hundred billion surrounding mountain ranges, hundred billion enlightening beings being born, hundred billion enlightening beings leaving home, hundred billion Buddhas realizing true enlightenment, hundred billion Buddhas teaching, hundred billion Buddhas passing away, a hundred billion polar mountain kings, a hundred billion heavens of hosts of celestial kings, a hundred billion heavens of thirty-three celestial realms, a hundred billion heavens of timely portion, a hundred billion heavens of satisfaction, a hundred billion heavens of enjoyment of emanations, a hundred billion heavens of free enjoyment of others’ emanations, a hundred billion heavens of pure hosts, a hundred billion light-sound heavens, a hundred billion heavens of purity, a hundred billion heavens of vast rewards, a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form; everything therein was all clearly manifest.

ji ltar 'di ni bcom ldan 'das sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs shing byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang thabs cig tu bzhugs te bskor cing mdun du byas par snang ba de bzhin du 'dzam bu'i gling bye ba phrag brgya kun na yang de bzhin gshegs pa bye ba phrag brgya bzhugs par snang ngo/ / de dag thams cad du'ang sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcu nas byang chub sems dpa' bcu bcu 'ongs par gyur te/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar 'jam dpal dang / sangs rgyas dpal dang / nor dpal dang / rin chen dpal dang / yon tan dpal dang / mig gi dpal dang / brtson 'grus dpal dang / chos kyi dpal dang / ye shes dpal dang / bzang po'i dpal zhes bya ba dag go/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa dag ste/ 'di ltar gser gyi mdog dang / yid du 'ong ba'i mdog dang / pad+mo'i mdog dang / tsam pa ka'i mdog dang / ut+pa la'i mdog dang / sa le sbram gyi mdog dang / rin po che'i mdog dang / rdo rje'i mdog dang; shel gyi mdog dang / 'dra ba'i mdog ces bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan 'di zhes bya ba de dag gi zham ring na tshangs pa'i spyad pa spyod de/ 'di ltar rig byed mi g.yo ba dang / rig byed mi bskyod pa dang / rig byed bcings pa med pa dang / rig byed kun spyod pa dang / rig byed sgrib pa med pa dang / rig byed mtha' rgal dang / rig byed dam pa dang / rig byed dbang phyug dang / rig byed tshangs pa dang / rig byed sna tshogs zhes bya ba dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang byang chub sems dpa' re re zhing byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan cig tu phyin te/ gcig ji lta ba de bzhin du thams cad do/ /

As in this place the Buddha, the World Honored One, was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne, surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, so also sat the hundred billion Buddhas in a hundred billion continents. In each case, because of the spiritual force of the Buddhas, in each of the ten directions was a great enlightening being, each with a company of as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, who came to the Buddha. Their names were Manjushri, Chief of the Awakened, Chief in Riches of Truth, Chief of the Precious, Chief of the Virtuous, Chief in Vision, Chief in Effort, Chief in Doctrine, Chief in Knowledge, and Chief in Goodness. The lands from whence these enlightening beings came were respectively called Golden World, Sublime Color World, Lotus Color World, Saffron Flower Color World, Blue Lotus Color World, Gold Color World, Jewel Color World, Diamond Color World, Crystal Color World, and Equal Color World. These enlightening beings had each cultivated pure practice in the company of Buddhas—the Buddha of Immutable Knowledge, the Buddha of Unhindered Knowledge, the Buddha of Knowledge of Liberation, the Buddha of Knowledge of Dignified Conduct, the Buddha of Knowledge of Characteristics, the Buddha of Ultimate Knowledge, the Buddha of Supreme Knowledge the Buddha of Independent Knowledge, the Buddha of Pure Knowledge, and the Buddha of Observing Knowledge.

thams cad na yang byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal zhes bya ba sha stag don 'di nyid brjod de/ gcig na ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad na yang ste/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang so so nas smra bar gyur to/ /
Then the Manjushris in all places, in the presence of each of the Buddhas, spoke up simultaneously and said in verse,

'jig rten kun dang mi ldan zhing / / bral bar gyur te dngos med pa'i/ / yang dag sangs rgyas su shes pa/ / de dag mig gi lam mi gnas/ /
shes rab chen po sus mthong zhing / / dngos po'i 'du shes mi 'jug la/ / rnam par bsgoms shing shes gyur pa/ / de dag de bzhin gshegs par 'gyur/ /
'jig rten khams 'di mthong gyur te/ / sangs rgyas che ba nyid dag la/ / gang gi sems ni mi g.yo ba/ / de dag mi yi mchog tu 'gyur/ /
sangs rgyas chos la gang gi rnams/ / mnyam pa'i sems su rab 'jug cing / / mi gnyis mngon gyur brtan pa rnams/ / de dag bsam gyis mi khyab 'gyur/ /
gang rnams bdag dang sangs rgyas dag / rang bzhin mnyam par rab gnas shing / / mi gnas len pa med pa rnams/ / de dag bde bar gshegs par 'gyur/ /
gzugs dang tshor ba 'du shes dang / / rnam par shes dang sems dpa' dag / grangs med de bzhin gshegs pa rnams/ / de dag thub pa chen por 'gyur; ;
blta bar bya las 'das pa dang / / rnam par blta las de bzhin te/ / chos la gang dag rmongs med pa/ / de dag rab tu 'od byed 'gyur/ /
gang gis shes rab chen po rnams; ; sems bskyed kun la rab gnas shing / / thams cad mthong yang skye med pa/ / de dag grags pa chen por 'gyur/ /
sems can rnams la skye ba med/ / 'jig pa'ang yod pa ma yin te/ / de ltar gang gis shes pa ni/ / de dag bla na med par 'gyur/ /
gang gis gcig la mang shes shing / / mang po'ang gcig tu rab rtogs te/ / gnas kyi rnams su 'ang 'byung 'gyur pa/ / de dag 'jigs pa med par 'gyur/ /

If any see the Truly Awake As becoming liberated and divorced from taints And not attached to any world, They have not realized the eye of the Way.
If any know the Buddha’s Substance and form have no existence, And by cultivation gain clear understanding, Such people will soon be Buddhas.
Who can see this world Unstirred in mind, And likewise Buddha’s body, Will attain supreme knowledge.
If, regarding the Buddha and truth, One understands that they are equal, Having no thought of duality, One will walk on the inconceivable plane.
If one sees the Buddha and oneself Resting in equality, Without abode, entering nowhere, One will become one of the Rare.
Form and feeling have no sets: Nor do conception, action, consciousness; Any who can know this way Will become great sages.
Whether mundane or transmundane views, Having risen beyond them all While well able to know the truth, One will become a great illuminate.
If, toward omniscience, One engenders dedication, Seeing mind without origination, One will gain the greatest name.
Living beings have no birth, Nor either any decay; If one attains such knowledge as this, One will realize the unexcelled way.
In one understanding infinity, Within infinity, one: Realizing their origin’s interdependent One will attain to fearlessness.

shel gyi mdog dang / 'dra ba'i mdog ces bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan 'di zhes bya ba dag gi zham ring na tshangs pa'i spyad pa spyod pa dag ste/ 'di ltar rig byed mi g.yo ba dang / rig byed mi bskyod pa dang / rig byed bcings pa med pa dang / rig byed kun spyod pa dang / rig byed bsgribs pa med pa dang / rig byed mtha' rgal dang / rig byed dam pa dang / rig byed dbang phyug dang / rig byed tshangs pa dang / rig byed sna tshogs zhes bya ba dag go/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang byang chub sems dpa' re re zhing byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan cig tu phyin pa dag ste/ gcig ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad do/ /

Then the light beams passed this world and illuminated ten lands in the eastern direction, also doing likewise in the South, West, North, the four intermediate directions, and the zenith and nadir. In all of those worlds were a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and so on, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, ten great enlightening beings from the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha; those enlightening beings were called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were called Immutable Knowledge, etc.

thams cad na yang byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal zhes bya ba sha stag don 'di nyid brjod de/ gcig na ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad na brjod de/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang so so nas smra bar gyur to/ /
Then the Manjushris in all those places, each in the presence of the Buddha in that place, all simultaneously spoke out, saying these verses:

gang gis 'gro ba shin tu gtses gyur cing / / srid pa'i gsal shing ldan par kun shes nas/ / rang 'byung kun mkhyen yon tan tshol ba rnams/ / de dag chos nyid 'di 'dra 'di bzhin no/ /
chos kyi rang bzhin gnas pa mthong gyur nas/ / mtha' gnyis gang gis rab tu spangs gyur cing / / ldog pa med cing dgos pa kun shes pa/ / de dag de yi 'khor lo mtshungs med bskor/ /
gang rnams chos dang ldan pa'i bsam pa yis/ / 'khor ba'i skye rgu kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / bskal pa bsam yas rgya chen go gyon pa'i/ / drang srong chen po'i longs spyod 'di 'dra'o/ /
gzhan gyis mi pham dpa' ba'i rgyal mtshan can/ / bdud rnams thams cad mthar 'byin mgon po rnams/ / byams pas gang dag mi 'jigs sgra 'byin pa/ / de dag chos nyid 'di 'dra 'di yin no/ /
'di dag nang nas byung ngo zhes bya bar/ / nyon mongs sel ba'i sems ni skad cig tu/ / thams cad shes pa su yi rgyud skyes pa/ / de dag rnam par 'phrul pa 'di dag ston/ /
gang rnams chos kyi rnga ni rdung byed cing / / byang chub sems kyang srog chags thams cad la/ / phyogs bcu'i zhing rnams kun tu shes byed pa/ / rang byung de dag tshul ni 'di 'dra'o/ /
gdul bar dka' ba mtha' yas spyod yul can/ / zhing rnams bye ba gang dag spyod gyur cing / / nam yang dngos po dag la mos med pa/ / de dag de bzhin gshegs bzhin rnam par 'phrul/ /
gang rnams dga' zhing mos pa mtha' yas pa/ / rgyal ba rnams ni shin tu rnam dag cing / / de bzhin gshegs pa mkha' 'dra rjes 'dra ba/ / de dag la ni smon lam 'di yang btab/ /
sems can don la gang rnams mos gyur cing / / re re dag gi mnar med sdug bsngal ba/ / bskal pa dpag med smin par bya dad pa/ / de dag skyon med pham med shin tu gsung / /
gang rnams lus dang srog la mi lta zhing / / sangs rgyas chos la rtag tu brtul zhugs te/ / mkhas pa bdag med rnam par su spyod pa/ / de dag sangs rgyas chos nyid 'di 'thob bo/ /

Sentient beings lack wisdom, Wounded and poisoned by the thorns of craving; For their sake we seek enlightenment: Such is the law of all Buddhas.
Seeing all things, Giving up extremes, Once enlightened, never regressing, They turn the incomparable wheel of truth.
For inconceivable eons Cultivating various practices vigorously In order to liberate beings: This is the power of the great sages.
The Guide conquers demons Bravely and invincibly, Preaching subtle truths in his light Because of kind compassion.
By knowledge and wisdom Breaking the barriers of afflictions, In an instant seeing all: This is the spiritual power of Buddhas.
Beating the drum of the great teaching, Awakening all lands in the ten directions, Making all turn toward enlightenment: Independent power can act like this.
Without breaking the infinite boundaries, Traveling through the billions of lands Without attachment to any existent: Such is freedom like the Buddhas’.
The Buddhas are like space, Ultimately forever pure; Those who rejoice in remembering this Will fulfill all of their vows.
In each and every one of the hells They pass innumerable eons; In order to liberate sentient beings They’re able to bear these pains.
Without begrudging body or life, Always preserving the Buddhas’ teachings, With egoless mind harmonious, One can attain the enlightened way.

Then the light beams passed ten worlds and illuminated a hundred lands in the eastern direction, also doing likewise in every other direction. In all of those worlds were a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and so on, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, ten great enlightening beings, from the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha; those enlightening beings were called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were called Immutable Knowledge, etc.

thams cad na yang byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal zhes bya ba sha stag don 'di nyid brjod de/ gcig na ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad na yang brjod de/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang so so nas smra bar gyur to/ /
Then the Manjushris in all those places, each in the presence of the Buddha in that place, all simultaneously spoke out, saying these verses:

bcom ldan 'das kyis sgyu ma'i rang bzhin du/ / thugs su chud nas bsgrib pas med gzigs te/ / zil gyis ma non chags pa mi mnga' bar/ / skye rgu rab tu 'dul bar shin tu snang / /
la las gser gyi ri bo 'dra ba de/ / sku tsher skye bar gyur pa rab tu mthong / / skyes bu'i zla ba rnam par mdzes pa de/ / tha ma'i sku yang 'dzin par la las mthong / /
yon tan tshad las 'das pa kun mnga' zhing / / dgongs pa mkhyen bzhin shin tu mkhas gyur pa/ / skye rgu'i seng+ge don yod gshegs pa de/ / la las 'chag cing gshegs par shin tu mthong / /
phyogs bcu kun tu rnam par snang ba de/ / la las mthon mthing spyan du de bzhin mthong / / 'dod pa'i yon tan ldan pa'i skye rgu rnams/ / gzigs nas bzhad par de bzhin la las mthong / /
gzi brjid mtshungs med mnga' la la la yis/ / seng+ge'i nga ror gsung ba de bzhin mthong / / zil gyis mi non ma log gsung mnga' ba/ / sku yi tha mar ston pa la las mthong / /
bcings pa kun las rnam par grol ba de/ / la las khab nas 'byung bar rab tu mthong / / sngon gyi rgyal ba'i sangs rgyas spyod pa rnams/ / gzigs shing zhi bder gzhol ba la las mthong / /
la las byang chub snying po dam pa la/ / chos rnams thams cad mngon par sangs rgyas shing; / yon tan thams cad pha rol phyin pa dang / / mun pa rdul bsal nyon mongs sbyangs pa mthong / /
la las chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba yang / / thugs rje chen po brnyes pa de mthong ngo/ / la las skye rgu tshad med rnam 'dul bar; ; skyes bu'i dam pa de ni de bzhin mthong / /
la las gzi brjid mtshungs pa med pa de/ / 'jig rten thams cad zil gyis mnan mdzad de/ / rdzu 'phrul chags med bla med stobs mnga' ba/ / seng+ge'i nga ro sgrog par de bzhin mthong / /
la las rab tu zhi ba'i thugs mnga' ba/ / 'jig rten sgron ma mya ngan 'das par mthong / / rnam par 'phrul pa de dag mthong nas kyang / / stobs bcu'i stobs mnga' de dag rab tu shes/ /

Buddha understands things are like phantoms; Comprehending, he is unhindered. His mind is pure and free from attachments; He harmonizes and pacifies all beings.
Some see him first born, His color like a mountain of gold; Living in his final body, He’s forever a moon of humanity.
Some see him walking around, Replete with boundless virtues; Attention and intellect well employed, The Great Man walks like a lion.
Some see his violet eyes Gazing in the ten directions; Sometimes he shows a smile, To accommodate beings’ wishes.
Some see his lion roar, His supreme, incomparable body Manifesting his last incarnation, Speaking naught but the truth.
Some see him leaving home, Shedding all bonds, Practicing the acts of Buddhas, Always contemplating extinction.
Some see him sitting on the enlightenment site Awakening knowledge of all things, Reaching the other shore of all virtues, Darkness and affliction ended.
Some see the supreme man Full of great compassion Turning the wheel of teaching Liberating numberless beings.
Some see the lion roar, Its awesome light unique, Transcending all the worlds With peerless mystic power.
Some see the mind at peace, Like a lamp gone out forever; Variously manifesting spiritual mastery, The ten-powered one can be like this.

de nas 'od zer de dag 'jig rten gyi khams de dag nas 'das te shar phyogs logs su 'jig rten gyi khams stong snang bar byas pa nas gzhung de bzhin du steng gi phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams stong gi bar du snang bar byas te 'jig rten gyi khams re rer yang 'dzam bu'i gling bye ba phrag brgya bstan pa nas 'og min bye ba phrag brgya'i bar du bstan to/ / 'jig rten gyi khams de dag gi khongs su gang ci yang rung ste gtogs par gyur pa de dag thams cad ril gyis bstan to/ / ji ltar bcom ldan 'das sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs par snang ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams re re'i gling bzhi pa bye ba phrag brgya kun na yang de bzhin gshegs pa sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs par snang ngo/ / thams cad du'ang sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcu nas byang chub sems dpa' bcu bcu 'ongs par gyur to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar 'jam dpal zhes bya ba nas bzang po'i dpal gyi bar du'o/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa dag ste/ 'di ltar gser gyi mdog ces bya ba nas 'dra ba'i mdog ces bya ba'i bar dag go/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan 'di zhes bya ba'i zham ring na tshangs pa'i spyad pa spyod pa dag ste; 'di ltar rig byed mi g.yo ba zhes bya ba nas rig byed sna tshogs zhes bya ba'i bar dag go/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang re re zhing byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra pa snyed dang lhan cig phyin pa dag ste/ gcig ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad do/ /

Then the light beams passed a hundred worlds and illumined a thousand worlds in each of the ten directions. In all of those worlds were a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and soon, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each one of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, ten great enlightening beings from the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha, those enlightening beings were also called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were also called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were also called Immutable Knowledge, etc.

thams cad na yang byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal zhes bya ba sha stag don 'di nyid brjod de/ gcig na ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad na yang brjod do/ / de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang so so nas smra par gyur to/ /
Then the Manjushris in all those places, simultaneously spoke up, saying these verses:

gang gis bde gshegs rnams kyi chos zab pa/ / zil gyis non pa brjod pa med pa rnams/ / gang la 'jig rten rtag tu mos 'gyur ba/ / de dag thams cad rim gyis rab tu ston/ /
gal te bdag cag med du zin na ni/ / de yi spyod yul stong pa zhi ba'ang med/ / rang byung rdul rnams shin tu bsal ba yi/ / bde gshegs rnams kyi sku yang ji ltar 'byung / /
mkhyen dang rnam grol zhabs dang ldan pa rnams/ / mtshungs pa med la grangs kyang nam yang med/ / de ni 'jig rten 'di na la la dag / rgyu la thogs pa med par 'dod phyir ro/ /
gang la phung po med cing khams med de/ / skye mched dag dang skye zhing 'chi med pa/ / de yi grangs ni 'jig rten 'di brnyes pas/ / skyes bu seng+ge rnams su rab tu brjod/ /
nang dang phyi zhes bya bar gdags pa rnams/ / de dag rang bzhin dngos nyid song ba ste/ / rtog pa med cid [*cing?] rnam rtog de bzhin med/ / gzhal du med pa'i chos nyid 'di 'dra'o/ /
de dag la ni g.yo pa nam yang med/ / snyems shing ldeg dang sgrib pa gang yang med/ / 'jig rten thams cad rjes su rab tu mkhyen/ / mtha' yas 'dul ba'i tshul ni 'di 'dra'o/ /
zhi ba'i ting 'dzin spyod yul dgyes pa rnams/ / rtse gcig gnyis la spyod pa'ang ma yin te/ / yid kyis gsog pa'ang de la gang yang med/ / 'dir ni sangs rgyas rnam 'phrul mtha' yas pa'o/ /
rgyu dang rkyen dang bya ba rnams dag dang / / las kyi rnam smin sems can spyod pa yis/ / rgyal ba rnams kyi ye shes mi ldog ste/ / bde gshegs chos ni de ltar bsam mi khyab/ /
phyogs rnams bcu na ji ltar 'khod pa yi/ / 'jig rten rnam pa sna tshogs kun gzigs shing / / sems can tshad med yongs su 'brel mdzad kyang / / skyes bu'i dbang po de dag rtog mi mnga'/ /
thams cad mkhyen pa nyid ni gser gyi mchog / de yang kun na rnam par kun na gnas/ / de dag bsam pa ci 'dra ji bzhin du/ / thub pa rnams ni de ltar chos kyang ston/ /

The Buddha comprehends, without peer, The exceedingly profound truth; Sentient beings cannot understand, So he reveals it step-by-step.
The nature of self has never existed, And possessions of self are also nil; So how come the enlightened ones Are able to have their bodies?
The liberated ones, with knowledge and conduct, Are beyond category or compare; All the logic and reasoning of the world Cannot find any fault in them.
The Buddhas are not worldly clusters, Elements, senses, born and dying things; Phenomenal sets cannot produce them: Thus they’re called human lions.
Their nature is fundamentally empty and inactive, They’re liberated within and without; Detached from all delusive ideas: Such is the peerless state.
Their substance and nature never moves, Selfless, no coming or going; Yet they can awaken the worlds, Pacifying all, without bound.
They always enjoy contemplating extinction, Uniform, without duality; Their minds do not increase or decrease, Yet manifest boundless powers.
They do not do the deeds That cause results for sentient beings, Yet can understand unhindered: Such is the enlightened way.
All kinds of living beings Transmigrate through all realms; Buddhas, not discriminating, Liberate the boundless kinds.
The Buddhas’ golden color Is not existent, yet pervades all existences; According to the inclinations of beings, They teach them ultimate peace.
bam po bcu bdun pa/

de nas 'od zer de dag 'jig rten gyi khams de dag nas 'das te shar phyogs logs su 'jig rten gyi khams stong phrag bcu snang bar byas so/ / gzhung de bzhin du steng gi phyogs su 'jig rten gyi khams stong phrag bcu snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams re rer 'dzam bu'i gling bye ba phrag brgya bstan pa nas 'og min bye ba phrag brgya'i bar du bstan te/ 'jig rten gyi khams de dag gi khongs su gang ci yang rung ste gtogs par gyur pa de dag thams cad ril gyis bstan to/ / ji ltar bcom ldan 'das sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs shing / byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang thabs cig par snang ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams re re dag gi gling bzhi pa bye ba phrag brgya kun na'ang de bzhin gshegs pa bye ba phrag brgya bzhugs par snang ste/ thams cad du'ang sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs nas byang chub sems dpa' bcu bcu 'ongs par gyur to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar 'jam dpal nas bzang po'i dpal zhes bya ba'i bar dag go/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa dag ste/ 'di ltar gser gyi mdog nas 'dra ba'i mdog gi bar dag go/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan 'di zhes bya ba dag gi zham ring na tshangs pa'i spyad pa spyod pa dag ste/ 'di ltar rig byed mi g.yo ba nas rig byed sna tshogs zhes bya ba dag go/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad re re zhing byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan cig tu phyin pa dag ste/ gcig ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad do/ / thams cad na yang byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal zhes bya ba sha stag don 'di nyid brjod de/ gcig na ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad na yang brjod de; de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang so so nas smra bar gyur to/ /

Then the light beams passed a thousand worlds and illumined ten thousand worlds in all directions; in all of those worlds were a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and so on, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each one of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, a great enlightening being from each of the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha; those enlightening beings were also called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were also called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were also called Immutable Knowledge, etc. Then the Manjushris in all those places, each in the presence of the Buddha in that place, all simultaneously spoke out, saying these verses:

lha dang 'jig rten bcas pa zil mnan te/ / snying rje la ni gang zhig sems gtong zhing / / 'gro ba thams cad bskyab par zhugs pa rnams/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /
bde gshegs rnams la snying nas dad bskyed cing / / gang gi sems ni nam yang mi ldog par/ / sangs rgyas spyod pa yongs su mi gtong ba/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /
gang rnams gang du'ang 'jug pa yod med cing / / sangs rgyas yon tan rnams las mi ldog pa/ / shin tu brtan pa blo gdung med pa rnams/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur par 'ong / /
gang rnams 'gro zhing 'dug dang 'chag pa'i tshe/ / nyin mtshan rgyan du rjes su sems byed cing / / sangs rgyas bdag nyid che ba sems spel ba/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /
dus gsum thams cad rab tu gzhal byas kyang / / gang gi sems ni zhum par mi 'gyur zhing / / sangs rgyas yon tan rjes su slob mos pa/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /
bdag gi rang bzhin yongs su gzhal byas shing / / thams cad ma lus zhi bar byed pa dang / / bdag dang bdag med 'dod chags bral ba'i sems/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /
gzhan gyis bsam pa yongs su gzhal byas shing / / rtog dang rnam rtog thams cad rab spangs te/ / spyod pa 'di 'dra dag dang ldan gyur pa/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /
gang rnams bsam gyis mi khyab zhing 'jal zhing / / sems can rgya mtsho yid kyis 'thung byed de/ / blo chen rdzu 'phrul stobs dang ldan gyur pa; ; de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /
gang gis zhing rnams rnam par bsam pa na/ / gzugs dang gzugs med 'du shes yongs med pa/ / thams cad grangs su nye bar 'gro ba ni/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /
gang rnams zhing ni rdul tu gzhig byas shing / / thams cad phyogs su bkang zhing bgrang byas te/ / de dag nang du rgyal ba 'dzud byed pa/ / de dag las ni 'di 'drar 'gyur bar 'ong / /

Developing great compassion To save and protect all sentient beings, Forever leaving human and celestial realms: This is what work should be done.
Always with faith in the Buddha, The mind never regressing, Associating with the enlightened ones: This is what work should be done.
Intent on the virtues of buddhahood, The will never receding, Abiding in pure cool wisdom: This is what work should be done.
In all manner of activities, Always remembering the Buddhas’ virtues, Without ever a lapse day or night: This is what work should be done.
Observing the boundless past, present, and future, Studying enlightened virtues Without ever tiring of it: This is what work should be done.
Observing the real characteristics of the body, All being void and nil, Detaching from self, with no egotism: This is what work should be done.
A mind seeing beings as equal, Not creating discrimination, Entering the realm of real truth: This is what work should be done.
Lifting up boundless worlds, Drinking up all the oceans: This power of knowledge of psychic attainment Is the kind of work that should be done.
Contemplating the various lands, Their material and immaterial aspects, Able to know them all: This is what work should be done.
The atoms of all lands everywhere Are, each and every one, a Buddha; To be able to know their number: This is what work should be done.

Then the light beams passed ten thousand worlds and illuminated a hundred thousand worlds in all directions. In all of those worlds were a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and so on, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, a great enlightening being from each of the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha; those enlightening beings were called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were called Immutable Knowledge, etc. Then the Manjushris in all those places, each in the presence of the Buddha in that place, all simultaneously spoke out, saying these verses:

mi 'dul kha lo sgyur ba mthu chen la/ / gang dag kha dog rigs kyis lta 'dod pa/ / mig nyams log par lta bar gyur pa ste/ / de dag rgyal ba'i chos nyid mi shes so/ /
de bzhin gshegs pa'i kha dog dbyibs dag ni/ / 'jig rten kun na'ang shes par nus pa med/ / gang gis bskal pa bye bar bsam byas kyang / / mthu chen rnams kyi kha dog mtha' med do/ /
de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan nyid mi mnga' ste/ / chos rnams thams cad mtshan nyid med cing dben/ / yan lag kun ldan blta na nyams med pa/ / bsam pa ji bzhin kun na rab tu snang / /
sangs rgyas chos rnams gzhal du yod pa min/ / gang rnams ci yang 'di yi tshul bshad de/ / ldan pa ma yin mi ldan ma yin pas/ / sangs rgyas chos rnams rang bzhin rab tu dben/ /
de bzhin gshegs pa phung po 'jig pa med/ / 'byung dang 'jig par spro ba mi mdzad de/ / mnga' brnyes mnga' sgyur rnam par gdon mi za/ / brjod du med pa rten pa rnam par spyod/ /
lus dang sems kyang mnyam par rab gyur cing / / nang dang phyi yis rnam par dben pas na/ / gnyis po bgrang du mi rung shes pa rnams/ / chags med bcings med bde bar gshegs par 'gyur/ /
gya nom snang zhing thugs gsal 'od mdzad pa/ / spyod yul yongs dag kun tu snang gyur te/ / thams cad mkhyen pa kun gzigs kun na bzhugs/ / skye rgu'i don kyang rgya chen yangs pa mdzad/ /
gcig tu gyur cing mang por rab tu 'gyur/ / mang por gyur cing gcig tu de bzhin 'gyur/ / 'gro ba'i khams ni du mar thugs chud cing / / thams cad tshul dang 'dra bar rab tu 'gyur/ /
sku med de la chags pa gang yang med/ / byon pa med cing bsags pa yod min yang / / kha dog mtha' yas rnam par dgod byas shing / / 'gro ba sna tshogs lus su de dag snang / /
'jig rten thams cad sems kyis brtags pa yin/ / sems ni rtogs pa nam yang ma yin te/ / bde gshegs ye shes de 'dra'i rang bzhin no/ / de phyir rgyal ba'i sku ni 'di 'drar snang / /

If one sees the Human Tamer In terms of form or family, These are diseased eyes, perverted views: They can’t know the supreme truth.
The various formal characteristics of the Buddha Cannot be assessed by any being; Though billions and trillions together calculate, Those features and virtues are yet more boundless.
The Buddha does not have forms as substance: It’s just the formless, quiescent state: Yet the physical forms and dignities are complete, Seen by worldlings in accord with their wishes.
The Buddhas’ reality is subtle and hard to fathom; No words or speech can reach it. It is not compounded or uncompounded; Its essential nature is void and formless.
Buddha’s body is unborn, beyond imagination; It is not a cluster of diverse elements. Having the power of freedom and certain insight, He travels the fearless, inexpressible path.
Body and mind equanimous, Liberated within and without, Abiding forever in true awareness, He has no attachment, no bondage.
The illumined one whose mind is pure Acts without habituation; With the eye of knowledge reaching everywhere He greatly aids living beings.
One body is infinite, And the infinite too are one; Understanding all the worlds, He manifests forms everywhere.
This body comes from nowhere And accumulates nothing either; It is due to beings’ discrimination That they see various bodies of Buddha.
Mind discriminates worlds, But that mind has no existence; The enlightened know this truth, And thus see the Buddha-body.

Then the light beams passed a hundred thousand worlds and illumined a million worlds, in each of the ten directions. In all of those worlds with a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and so on, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, ten great enlightening beings from the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha; those enlightening beings were called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were called Immutable Knowledge, etc. Then the Manjushris in all those places, each in the presence of the Buddha in that place, all simultaneously spoke out, saying these verses:

'jig rten rang byung de las mchog med pa/ / mi gnas dam pa phul dang mchog gi rnams; ; drang srong chen po srid pa'i rgyud 'grel pa/ / yon tan kun ldan rnam dag 'di yin no/ /
'du 'dzi med cing chags pa mi mnga' la/ / 'du shes dngos med gnas pa med pa rnams/ / phun sum dge ldan smad pa mi mnga' ba/ / mgon po rnams kyi chos nyid thub par dka'/ /
shin tu 'od snang dag par gyur pa rnams/ / brgal du glags med rnyog pa med pa'i rnams/ / g.yo med mtha' ma rnam par spangs pa yi/ / bde gshegs rnams kyi ye shes tshul 'di yin/ /
lus dang sems la rnam par rtog med cing / / bde gshegs chos la gang zhig 'jug 'gyur ba/ / de dag chos rnams kun gyi rang bzhin la/ / nam yang nem nur dbang du mi 'gro'o/ /
'jig rten dag na dmigs pa gang yod pa/ / de dag kun la bstan pa'i chos 'jug ste/ / gang dag phyir rgol med pas bstan mdzad kyang / / rang bzhin ldog par 'gyur ba gang yang med; ;
dngos po rab shes las rnams yod min par/ / the tshom thams cad rnam par spangs byas te/ / sangs rgyas byang chub rab tu rtogs pa'i tshe/ / sems la rnam par 'byed pa nam yang med/ /
mi shes chos rnams rnam par phye ba dag / byung med tshig gi lam gyis rab brjod pa/ / sangs rgyas gsung gi rjes su 'brangs byas na/ / gcig kyang ma yin mang po'ang ma yin no/ /
mang dang gcig pa nam yang yod min te/ / mang po rnams la gcig pa yod med do/ / mang dang gcig pa rnam par bsgoms byas na/ / sangs rgyas yon tan mtha' yas shes par 'gyur/ /
'jig rten kun tu sems can zhing rnams dang / / shin tu zhi ba'i chos rnams rnam bltas te/ / mi gnas sems la rtog pa med pa yi/ / dran ldan sangs rgyas byang chub thob par 'gyur/ /
sems can chos dang de bzhin zhing gi rnams/ / de dag rang bzhin ji bzhin brtags byas na/ / gcig dang tha dad gyur pa ma yin te/ / de ltar sangs rgyas tshul 'di shes pa yin/ /

The enlightened one most free, Transcending the world, relying on nothing, Replete with all virtues, Liberates creatures from all states of being.
Unaffected, unattached, Without conceptions, resting nowhere, Substance and essence immeasurable: Those who see all praise.
Light pervasive, clear and pure, Clearing away mundane afflictions, Immutable, beyond extremes: This is enlightened knowledge.
Any who see the enlightened Free from discrimination in body and mind Will have no more doubts or hesitation In regard to anything.
In all worlds, everywhere Turning the wheel of teaching, Natureless, with nothing turned, The Guide expounds expedients.
Having no doubt as to truth, Forever ending mental fabrication, Not producing a discriminating mind: This is awareness of enlightenment.
Comprehending different things, Not sticking to verbal explanations, With no “one” or “manifold”: This is following Buddha’s teaching.
In many there’s no oneness; Neither has one plurality: Abandoning both of these, Comprehensively enter the qualities of buddhahood.
Sentient beings and their lands Are all completely null; With no reliance or discrimination One can enter Buddha’s enlightenment.
Of sentient beings and lands Unity or difference cannot be found; Insightfully seeing like this Is called knowing the meaning of Buddha’s teaching.

de nas 'od zer de dag 'jig rten gyi khams de dag nas 'das te shar phyogs logs su 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba snang bar byas nas steng gi phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba'i bar du snang bar byas te/ 'jig rten gyi khams re rer yang 'dzam bu'i gling bye ba phrag brgya bstan pa nas 'og min bye ba phrag brgya'i bar du bstan to/ / 'jig rten gyi khams de dag gi khongs su gang ci yang rung ste gtogs par gyur pa de dag thams cad ril gyis bstan to/ / ji ltar bcom ldan 'das sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs shing / byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang thabs cig par snang ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams re re'i gling bzhi pa bye ba phrag brgya kun na yang de bzhin gshegs pa bye ba phrag brgya dag sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs par snang ngo/ / thams cad du yang sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcu nas byang chub sems dpa' bcu bcu 'ongs par gyur to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar 'jam dpal zhes bya ba nas bzang po'i dpal gyi bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa dag ste/ 'di ltar gser gyi mdog ces bya ba nas 'dra ba'i mdog ces bya ba'i bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan 'di zhes bya ba dag gi zham ring na tshangs pa'i spyad pa spyod pa dag ste/ 'di ltar rig byed mi g.yo ba zhes bya ba nas rig byed sna tshogs zhes bya ba'i bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang byang chub sems dpa' re re zhing byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan cig tu phyin pa dag ste/ gcig ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad do/ / thams cad na yang byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal zhes bya ba sha stag don 'di nyid brjod de/ gcig na ji lta ba bde bzhin thams cad na yang brjod do/ / de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang so so nas smra bar gyur to; ;

Then the light beams passed a million worlds and illuminated a billion worlds in each of the ten directions. In all of those worlds were a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and so on, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, a great enlightening being from each of the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha; those great enlightening beings were called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were called Immutable Knowledge, etc. Then the Manjushris in all those places, each in the presence of the Buddha in that place, all simultaneously spoke out, saying these verses:

shes rab dpag med chos rnams mtha' yas pa/ / srid pa rgya mtsho'i pha rol phyin pa dag / tshe ring nad med mnyam med mtshungs med 'od/ / yon tan che mnga' 'di dag sbyor 'di'o/ /
gang gis sangs rgyas chos rnams dngos rtogs shing / / dus gsum kun tu brtags kyang mi ngoms te/ / dmigs pa shes byed rnam par mi rtog pa/ / bsam yas mos pa de dag sbyor 'di'o/ /
sems can yul mos sems can 'du shes med/ / 'jig tshogs chos shes lam gyi rgyud dang bral/ / bsam gtan nang dad sems la bcings pa med; ; chags med yid ldan de dag sbyor 'di yin/ /
rtogs mkhas rab tu rtogs pa'i chos can rnams/ / mya ngan 'das spyod rigs la brtson pa dag / thar pa'i lam brtson mnyam pa nyid ldan pa/ / zhi ba thob pa de dag sbyor 'di'o/ /
ded dpon rjes song sangs rgyas byang chub mchog / thams cad mkhyen pa chos dbyings bzhin rtogs shing / / bden 'jug mkhas pas sems can rnam 'dul ba/ / bde gshegs bsam gtan de dag sbyor 'di 'o/ /
sangs rgyas don tshig rjes su shes bya zhing / / chags med blo yangs rtogs shing bsam gtan byed/ / kun tu 'gro bar song bas rtsol spyod pa/ / rang byung spyod pa de dag sbyor 'di 'o/ /
nam mkha'i dbyings dang sprul pa yid ldan rnams/ / gnas dang rang bzhin mtshan nyid shes pa dag / mya ngan 'das rigs spyod pa mkha' 'dra rnams/ / thob dka' thob pa rnams kyi sbyor 'di 'o/ /
zla ba zla phyed nyin dang nub bgrang zhing / / lo dang bskal pa'i rang bzhin su sems pa/ / 'jig rten 'du zhing 'jig par 'gyur ba dang / / grangs tshul sus rtogs de dag sbyor 'di 'o/ /
zhing gi sems can ji snyed skye 'chi ba/ / gzugs dang gzugs med 'du shes 'du shes med/ / de dag ming dang gnas pa rtogs shes pa/ / bsam gyis mi khyab rtogs pa'i sbyor 'di 'o/ /
'das pa'i dus dang ma 'ongs da ltar la/ / ngag gi lam gyis gang na rtog byed cing / / dus gsum rang bzhin ji ltar rtogs gyur pa; ; mnyam med de dag sbyor ba 'di yin no/ /

Wisdom peerless, teaching boundless, Gone beyond the sea of existences, reaching the other shore, Life span and radiance without compare: This is the power of the Virtuous One’s skill.
Clearly understanding all the Buddhas’ teachings, Always observing all times tirelessly, Even when perceiving objects, not discriminating: This is the power of the Inconceivable One’s skill.
Contemplating sentient beings without any concept thereof, Observing all existences without such ideas, Always abiding in meditative stillness yet not binding the mind: This is the power of skill of unhindered wisdom.
Skillfully comprehending all things, With right mindfulness diligently cultivating the path of nirvana, Enjoying liberation, divorcing partiality: This is the power of skill of the peaceful, dispassionate one.
If any can exhort to complete enlightenment, Heading for all-knowledge of the cosmos, And influence beings to enter into truth: This is the power of skill of dwelling in the Buddha-mind.
Able to enter into all truths the Buddhas teach With vast knowledge and wisdom unobstructed, Able to arrive at every destination: This is the power of skill of cultivation of freedom.
Always abiding in nirvana, like empty space, Able to transform and appear anywhere at will: This is creating form based on the formless, The power of skill of the one who reaches the hard to reach.
Day and night, day and month, year and era, The signs of the beginning and end, formation and disintegration of the worlds: Remembering and thoroughly knowing these Is the power of skill of knowledge of measures of time.
All living beings have birth and death; Material and immaterial, thinking or unthinking: Knowing all the various names Is the power of skill of abiding in the inconceivable.
Of past, present, and future times, Understanding all that’s said, Yet knowing all times are equal: This is the power of skill of incomparable understanding.

de nas 'od zer de dag 'jig rten gyi khams de dag nas 'das te shar phyogs logs su 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba phrag bcu snang bar byas nas steng gi phyogs su 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba phrag bcu'i bar du snang bar byas te/ 'jig rten gyi khams re rer yang 'dzam bu'i gling bye ba phrag brgya bstan pa nas 'og min bye ba phrag brgya'i bar du bstan to/ / 'jig rten gyi khams de dag gi khongs su gang ci yang rung ste gtogs par gyur pa de dag thams cad ril gyis bstan to/ / ji ltar bcom ldan 'das sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs shing / byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang thabs cig par snang ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams re re'i gling bzhi pa bye ba phrag brgya dag kun na yang de bzhin gshegs pa bye ba phrag brgya dag sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs par snang ngo/ / thams cad du yang sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcu nas byang chub sems dpa' bcu bcu 'ongs par gyur to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar 'jam dpal zhes bya ba nas bzang po'i dpal gyi bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa dag ste/ 'di ltar gser gyi mdog ces bya ba nas 'dra ba'i mdog ces bya ba'i bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan 'di zhes bya ba dag gi zham ring na tshangs pa'i spyad pa spyod pa dag ste/ 'di ltar rig byed mi g.yo ba zhes bya ba nas rig byed sna tshogs zhes bya ba'i bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang byang chub sems dpa' re re zhing byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan cig tu phyin pa dag ste/ gcig ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad do/ / thams cad na yang byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal zhes bya ba sha stag don 'di nyid brjod do/ / gcig na ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad na yang brjod do/ / de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang so so nas smra bar gyur to/ /

Then the light beams passed a billion worlds and illuminated ten billion worlds in each of the ten directions. In all of those worlds were a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and so on, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, ten great enlightening beings from the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha; those great enlightening beings were called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were called Immutable Knowledge, etc. Then the Manjushris in all those places, each in the presence of the Buddha in that place, all simultaneously spoke out, saying these verses:
