'das dus gang gis sgrub dka'i brtul zhugs che brtsams shing / / nam yang zhum pa'i sems su gtong bar mi byed de/ / brgal dka' rgal te bdag gis sems can kun 'dul zhes/ / seng+ge'i sgra sgrog de dag spyod yul 'di yin no/ /
gang zhig 'dod dang sred pa 'byung zhing 'jug pa dang / / ma rig gzhol ba gti mug mang bsgribs 'jigs chen rnams/ / sems can rang bzhin bdag med brtan pa bzod par 'jug / bdag kyang 'jig rten mgon 'gyur zhes pa de yul 'di/ /
'jig rten sems can mang po 'dod dregs 'dam bying ba/ / med pa'i chos la rtog pas sdug bsngal mthong gyur nas/ / sangs rgyas spyod yul chos la bag yod gang spyod cing / / bdag gis sems can kun bsgral de dag spyod yul 'di; ;
mngon mtha' shes dka' tshad med brtan pas mthong gyur cing / / bdag rten sems can pha rol mtha' yas 'khor gyur pa/ / de dag rgyal bas theg pa zhi ba mchog la bkod/ / bdag gis de 'dra'i chos bstan de yi spyod yul lo/ /
sems can khams rnams mgon med nad kyis gzir gyur cing / / ngan song gzhol pa 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug gdungs/ / me lce 'bar phung 'jigs gzugs mi bzad bsregs gyur pa/ / mthong nas dgrol phyir zhugs pa de dag spyod yul 'di 'o/ /
lam gol lam ma yin pa'i rkyen la spyod gyur cing / / mun pa chen po rtol bar dka' rnyed 'gro mthong nas/ / snang ba chen po bskyed de sangs rgyas chos bstan ces/ / 'di skad tshig brjod de dag spyod yul 'di yin no/ /
srid pa'i mtshos g.yengs sems can rab tu mang ba dag / mtha' ma mi mthong skyabs med do zhes mi dga' ba/ / mthong nas brtson 'grus stobs bskyed chos kyi gru sbyar cing / / pha rol su 'gro zhes brjod de dag spyod yul 'di 'o/ /
sems can rtsa ba med la gnas pa mi mkhas kun/ / g.yang sa chen por lhung zhing sems nyams rmongs mthong nas/ / snying rjes chos kyi zam la mkhas pa su dgod cing / / dran par gyis shes su smra de dag spyod yul 'di 'o/ /
shin tu dog pa'i brtson rar sdug bsngal sems can rnams/ / na dang rga bas gzir cing tsham gyis mnar ba dag / mthong nas bdag gis thabs kyi chos rnams kun brtsams te/ / sems can kun 'grol sems dpa' de dag spyod yul 'di 'o/ /
sangs rgyas chos rnams thams cad thos gyur the tshom ma med/ / chos dbyings spyod yul phyogs bcu kun tu rgyas bkang ste/ / 'di dag thams cad brtags na gsog kyang mi gzigs shing / / sems can kun la snyoms byed de yi spyod yul lo/ /

Having cultivated extensive difficult practices, Diligently working day and night, Having crossed the hard to cross, with a lion’s roar, Teaching all beings—this is the practice.
Sentient beings whirl in the sea of craving and greed, Shrouded by the web of ignorance, terribly oppressed; The Most Benevolent bravely cuts it all away, We vow to also do so—this is the practice.
Worldlings have no control, attached to sense desires; Falsely discriminating, they suffer myriad pains. Practicing the Buddhas’ teaching, always control the mind, Vowing to cross over this—this is the practice.
Sentient beings, attached to self, enter birth and death; Looking for a limit to this, none can be found. Serving all the enlightened to obtain the wondrous teaching, Explain it to others—this is the practice.
Living beings are helpless, wrapped up in sickness, Forever sunk in evil ways, producing the three poisons, The fierce flames of a great fire always burning them; With a pure heart to rescue them, this is the practice.
Sentient beings, confused, have lost the right path; Always going the wrong way, they enter the house of darkness. For their sake lighting the lamp of truth, To be a light forever—this is the practice.
Sentient beings bob and sink in the ocean of existences; Their troubles are boundless, they have no place to rest. To make for them an ark of truth To ferry them over—this is the practice.
Sentient beings are ignorant and don’t see the fundamental; Confused, foolish, crazed, in the midst of danger and difficulty. Buddhas pity them and set up a bridge of teaching With right awareness, to let them climb—this is the practice.
Seeing beings on perilous paths, Oppressed by the pains of age, illness, and death, Develop unlimited skill in means And pledge to save them all—this is the practice.
Hearing the truth, believing without doubt, Comprehending essential emptiness without shock or fear, Appearing in all realms in appropriate forms, Teach all the deluded—this is the practice.

de nas 'od zer de dag 'jig rten gyi khams de dag nas 'das te shar phyogs logs su 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba phrag brgya snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba stong snang bar byas so/ / /'jig rten gyi khams bye ba brgya phrag stong snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba khrag khrig snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba khrag khrig brgya snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba khrag khrig stong snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba khrag khrig brgya phrag stong snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams tshad med pa snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams gzhal du med pa snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams grangs med pa snang bar bya so/ / de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ mtshungs pa med pa/ kun tu mtha' yas pa/ mu med pa/ sa mtshams med pa/ dpag tu med pa/ brjod du med pa dag kyang snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa/ nam mkha'i mthas gtugs pa thams cad kyang snang bar bya so/ / gzhung de bzhin du lho phyogs dang / de bzhin du nub phyogs dang de bzhin du byang phyogs dang / de bzhin du byang shar gyi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du shar lho'i phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du lho nub kyi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du nub byang gi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du 'og gi phyogs nas steng gi phyogs kyi bar du 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba stong snang bar byas nas nam mkha'i mthas gtugs pa'i bar gyi 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyang snang bar byas so/ / de ltar phyogs bcu shin tu rgyas par byas nas chos kyi dbyings ma lus pa thams cad kyang snang bar byas so/ / 'jig rten gyi khams re rer yang 'dzam bu'i gling bye ba phrag brgya bstan pa nas gzhung de bzhin du 'og min bye ba phrag brgya'i bar du bstan to/ / 'jig rten gyi khams de dag gi khongs su gang ci yang rung ste gtogs par gyur pa de dag thams cad kyang ril gyis bstan to; ; ji ltar bcom ldan 'das sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs shing / byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang thabs cig par snang ba de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams re re'i gling bzhi pa bye ba phrag brgya kun na yang de bzhin gshegs pa bye ba phrag brgya dag sangs rgyas kyi gdan la bzhugs par snang ngo/ / thams cad du yang sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcu nas byang chub sems dpa' bcu bcu 'ong par gyur to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar 'jam dpal zhes bya ba nas bzang po'i dpal gyi bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs pa dag ste/ 'di ltar gser gyi mdog ces bya ba nas 'dra ba'i mdog ces bya ba'i bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa mtshan 'di zhes bya ba dag gi zham ring na tshangs pa'i spyod pa spyad pa dag ste/ 'di ltar rig byed mi g.yo ba zhes bya ba nas rig byed sna tshogs zhes bya ba'i bar dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang byang chub sems dpa' re re zhing byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas kyi zhing bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed dang lhan cig tu phyin pa dag ste/ gcig ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad do/ / thams cad na yang byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal zhes bya ba sha stag don 'di nyid brjod do/ / gcig na ji lta ba de bzhin thams cad na yang brjod do/ / de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag kyang so so nas smra bar gyur to/ /

Then the light beams passed ten billion worlds and illumined in all ten directions a hundred billion worlds, a trillion worlds, a hundred trillion worlds, a quadrillion worlds, a hundred quadrillion worlds, a quintillion worlds, a hundred quintillion worlds; in this way countless, unquantifiable, boundless, imcomparable, uncountable, unaccountable, unthinkable, immeasurable, unspeakable numbers of worlds, to the utmost extent of the realm of space of the cosmos, in all ten directions, were likewise illumined. In all of those worlds were a hundred billion continents called Jambudvipa, and so on, including a hundred billion heavens of the ultimate of form—everything in all those realms was clearly revealed. In each of the Jambudvipa continents the Buddha was seen sitting on a lotus bank lion throne surrounded by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands; and in each one, due to the spiritual force of the Buddha, a great enlightening being from each of the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten buddha-lands, came to the Buddha; those great enlightening beings were called Manjushri, etc., the lands they came from were called Golden, etc., and the Buddhas they served were called Immutable Knowledge, etc. Then the Manjushris in all those places, each in the presence of the Buddha in that place, all simultaneously spoke out, saying these verses:

bskal pa gzhal yas bsam gyis mi khyab sems kyi skad cig la/ / gang gis mthong yang bsags med 'gro dang dngos po'i tshul med pa'i/ / lam du rab tu 'jug pa de na thams cad shes 'gyur te; ; stobs bcus tshul 'di ji ltar mkhyen bzhin 'jigs med sangs rgyas 'gyur/ /
grags pa snyan par phyogs rnams kun tu mtshungs med grags gyur cing / / bgegs rnams kun las 'das te chos nyid 'di la dgar spyad de/ / tshad med thams cad so sor zhi zhing don rnams kun rtogs pas/ / de phyir phyogs rnams kun bkang bde gshegs chos nyid 'di ston to/ /
dgongs pa ji bzhin de ni spyod pa'i 'bras bu mthun pa ste/ / 'jig rten don 'gyur de bzhin gshegs la mchod pa yang byas shing / / de dag thams cad so sor mthun par ye shes rnams bsgoms pas/ / sems can dam pa sangs rgyas rnam 'phrul 'di 'dra phyogs bcur ston/ /
thog mar nyan 'dod bla ma bsnyen bkur bzod pa des byas shing / / rang bzhin med pa'i chos la rab rtog bsam gtan bsnyen byed pa/ / bde gshegs nyid ni rtogs 'gyur 'gro ba rnam sgom sems tshim byed/ / chos nyid de 'dra spyod pa myur du bde gshegs thob par 'gyur/ /
snying nas 'dri zhing phyogs rnams rgyal byed rtse gcig thub byed cing / / rgyal ba'i yon tan mos las mi ldog spyod pas tshim byed pa/ / dngos dang dngos med thams cad shes byas spangs shing dngos zad pa'i/ / sangs rgyas bdag med dpe med mthong ba de dag lus 'di yin/ /
bzang po'i spyod yul can gyi sems kyis phyogs rnams kun bkang zhing / / zhing rnams thams cad chos kyi gter gyis khyab byas tshim byed pa/ / ji bzhin chos gnas chos nyid mtha' la the tshom med pa rnams/ / stobs bcu ci 'dra de bzhin gyur pa'i lus ni 'di dag go /
bcom ldan 'das kyis chos gang sgra brjod de la 'jug byed cing / / chos kyi 'khor lo ji bzhin blta dka' gzhal yas rtag bskor ba/ / de bzhin gshegs pas gsungs pa'i gsung kun byang chub yan lag rtogs/ / de ltar 'jug pas rtag tu sangs rgyas sku rab 'di dag mthong / /
mthong yang mig gi rnam shes tshul du rdul med mthong ba med/ / rnam shes sgyu ma bzhin pas mig stong stobs bcu mi mthong ngo/ / 'du shes thams cad rnam rtog yin gyi sangs rgyas mthong ba min/ / shin tu chags med yul med de ni rgyal ba mthong ba yin/ /
sems can las mang bsags pa de dag shin tu blta dka' ste/ / nang dang phyi dang dbyibs dang mdog tu phyogs bcu kun na med/ / de bzhin rang byung sku ni gzhal yas phyogs rnams kun 'gengs pa/ / shes par dka' ba 'dren pa chen po bsgribs pa med pas brnyes/ /
nam mkha' dag la zhing rnams bye ba dngos por gnas par snang / / de nas 'ong ba med cing phyogs bcu kun tu 'gro ba med/ / gcig cing gnas par 'gyur yang de dag ci la'ang gnas pa med/ / de bzhin rang byung rnams kyi sku ni mkha' dbyings rtag tu 'gengs/ /

In one instant observing measureless eons Without going, coming, or dwelling, Thus comprehending the events of past, present, and future, Buddhas transcend expedients and fulfill ten powers.
With incomparable good repute in all quarters, Forever out of trouble, always rejoicing, They go to all lands To explain such a teaching for all.
For the benefit of beings, they supported the enlightened, Attaining a comparable result, according to their will; Readily acknowledging all truths, They reveal spiritual powers everywhere.
From their first offerings to the enlightened their minds were flexible and patient; They entered deep meditative concentration and observed the nature of things. Exhorting all beings to aspire to enlightenment, Through this they speedily attained the unexcelled reward.
Who seeks truth everywhere with undivided mind To cultivate virtues to full maturity, Eliminating all duality of being and nonbeing: Such people truly see the Buddha.
Going to all lands in all directions, Expounding the sublime teaching for the welfare of the many, Abiding in reality without any wavering: Such people’s virtues are the same as Buddha.
The cycles of wondrous teaching turned by the Buddhas Are all aspects of enlightenment; If one, having heard, can realize the nature of things, Such a person will always see Buddha.
If one does not see the Ten Powered as empty, phantomlike, Though one sees one sees not, as though blind. Discriminating and grasping forms one does not see Buddha; Having finally divorced attachment, then can one see.
Sentient beings are variously different, according to their actions; In the ten directions, inside and out, it’s hard to see them all: The Buddha-body’s unhindered, pervading all directions, And cannot be completely seen, in just the same way.
Like unto the infinite worlds in space, Without coming or going, pervading the ten directions, Becoming and disintegrating having no resting place, So does Buddha pervade space in the same way.
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i 'od zer las rnam par sangs rgyas pa'i le'u ste/ bcu bzhi pa'o// //
[15. byang chub sems dpa' dris pa snang ba zhes bya ba'i le'u]
BOOK TEN. An Enlightening Being Asks for Clarification

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras/ rang bzhin gcig pa'i sems la bye brag tha dad pa'i rnam pa 'di lta bu dag 'di lta ste/ bde 'gror 'gro ba dang / ngan song du 'gro ba dang / dbang po tshang ba dang / dbang po ma tshang ba dang / skye ba mthun pa dang / skye ba mi mthun pa dang / sdug pa dang / mi sdug pa dang / bde ba myong ba dang / sdug bsngal myong ba snang ba dag la ltos/ las kyis ni/ sems mi shes so/ / sems kyis ni/ las mi shes so; ; tshor bas ni/ rnam par smin pa mi shes so/ / rnam par smin pas ni/ tshor ba mi shes so/ / sems kyis ni/ tshor ba mi shes so/ / tshor bas ni/ sems mi shes so; ; rgyus ni/ rkyen mi shes so/ / rkyen gyis ni/ rgyu mi shes so/ / dngos pos ni/ dmigs pa mi shes so/ / dmigs pas ni/ dngos po mi shes so/ /

THEN THE ENLIGHTENING BEING Manjushri asked the enlightening being Chief of the Awakened, “Since the nature of mind is one, what is the reason for seeing the existence of various differences, such as going to good or bad tendencies, having complete or imperfect faculties, differences in birth, beauty and ugliness, pain and pleasure, suffering and happiness? Why is it that activity doesn’t know mind, mind doesn’t know activity, reception doesn’t know consequence, consequence doesn’t know reception, mind doesn’t know reception, reception doesn’t know mind, cause doesn’t know condition, condition doesn’t know cause, knowledge doesn’t know object, object doesn’t know knowledge?”
de nas byang chub sems dpa' sangs rgyas dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/
Chief of the Awakened answered in verse, saying,

sems can bstan par bya ba'i phyir/ / gang 'di yongs su dris pa dag / chos rnams chos nyid ci 'dra ba/ / 'jam dpal bdag las mnyan par gyis/ /
chos rnams 'di dag g.yo ba med/ / shin tu dngos po med pa ste/ / de phyir gzhan gyis gzhan dag gi / ngo bo nyid kyang mi shes so/ /
ji ltar chu klung rgyud kyi rnams/ / gzhan dang gzhan du 'grogs rgyu yang / / gcig gis gcig ni mi shes te/ / chos kyi chos nyid de bzhin no; ;
ji ltar 'bar ba'i mtshan ma can/ / 'od 'phro gzhan dang gzhan 'grogs kyang / / gcig gis gcig ni mi shes te/ / chos kyi chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar rlung ni bsten tshul gyis; ; gzhan dang gzhan du rab tu rgyu/ / gcig gis gcig ni mi shes te/ / chos kyi chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar sa yi khams kyi rnams/ / gcig la gcig ni gnas gyur kyang / / gcig gis gcig ni mi shes te/ / chos kyi chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
mig dang rna ba sna dag dang / / lce dang lus dang yid kyi rnams/ / 'di dag las ni rgyu 'khod kyang / / byed pa po ni gang yang med/ /
'byung ba'i rang bzhin med pa yis/ / 'byung ba nye bar bstan byas kyang / / bstan par byas pa gang yang med/ / bstan pa la ni dngos med de/ /
mig ni rang bzhin nyid kyis stong / / rna ba sna yang rang bzhin gyis/ / lce dang lus dang yid rnams kyang / / med de yongs su brtags pa yin/ /
gang zhig rang bzhin dngos med par/ / tshul bzhin rab tu rtog byed pa/ / de yi mig la 'khrul pa med/ / chos mig bsam gyis mi khyab pa'o/ /
yang dag pa dang yang dag min/ / bden nam 'on te rdzun yang rung / / 'jig rten 'das dang 'jig rten kun/ / tshig gi lam gyis brjod pa'o/ /

Benevolent One, you ask the meaning of this To awaken all the ignorant. I will answer according to the essence: Listen clearly, Benevolent One.
Phenomena have no function And have no individual nature; Therefore all of them Do not know one another.
Like the waters in a river, Their rushing flow races past, Each unaware of the others: So it is with all things.
It’s also like a mass of fire, Blazing flames shoot up at once, Each not knowing the others: Phenomena are also thus.
Also like a continuous wind Fanning and drumming whatever it hits, Each unaware of the other: So also are all things.
Also like the various levels of earth, Each based on another, Yet unaware of the others: Thus are all phenomena.
Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, Mind, intellect, the faculties of sense: By these one always revolves, Yet there is no one, nothing that revolves.
The nature of things is fundamentally birthless, Yet they appear to have birth; Herein there is no revealer, And nothing that’s revealed.
Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, Mind, intellect, the faculties of sense: All are void and essenceless; The deluded mind conceives them to exist.
Seen as they truly are, All are without inherent nature. The eye of reality is not conceptual: This seeing is not false.
Real or unreal, False or not false, Mundane or transmundane: There’s nothing but descriptions.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' nor dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras/ sems can thams cad sems can med mod kyi/ 'on kyang de bzhin gshegs pa ni/ sems can 'dul ba'i dus la ji ltar 'bab pa dang / sems can gyi tshe ji lta ba dang / lus ji lta ba dang / spyod pa ji lta ba dang / mos pa ji lta ba dang / mtshan ma ji lta ba dang / bsam pa ji lta ba dang / sbyor ba ji lta ba dang; sems ji lta ba dang / spyod pa ji lta ba de bzhin du sems can rnams kyi sems can 'dul ba'i phyir mthong ngo/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' nor dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

Then Manjushri asked Chief in Riches of Truth, “Since all sentient beings are not sentient beings, why does the Buddha appear in their midst for their sake and teach them according to the time, according to their lives, according to their species, according to their actions, according to their understandings, according to their philosophies, according to their inclinations, according to their expedients, according to their thoughts, according to their observations?” Chief in Riches answered him in verse:

gang rnams rab tu zhi spyod cing / / thos dang ldan pa'i sa 'di yin/ / 'di don ci 'dra de bzhin du/ / 'jam dpal bdag las mnyan par gyis/ /
bdag gi lus la su gnas shes/ / gang gis nad ni rab shes pa/ / yang dag yod dam med pa'i don/ / des ni rab tu shes pa yin/ /
lus kyi rnam par dgod pa ni/ / phyogs na mi gnas brjod pa yin/ / de bas shes pa de gnas la/ / nam yang chags par mi byed do/ /
lus ni rnam par spyod pa yis/ / dngos po kun kyang rnam par bsgoms/ / sems ni phyir ldog mi 'gyur te/ / dngos po kun ni brtags pa'o/ /
gang gi tshe ni rjes su 'brang / / gang gi tshe ni phyir ldog 'gyur/ / ji ltar mgal me 'khor lo yi/ / thog ma tha ma 'khor ba bzhin/ /
dngos po thams cad mi rtag par/ / skye bo gang rnams rtog pa yang / / lus la bdag kyang med pa'i phyir/ / 'du shes phyir yang ldog par 'gyur/ /
bdag med rmi lam lta bu yi/ / las ni kun tu rab tu 'byung / / rnam par smin pas rab tu 'byung / / phyi ma ji bzhin sngon de bzhin/ /
sems ni dbang byed yin par bshad; ; dad pa'i tshul ni ji bzhin du/ / tshul bzhin ma yin phyin ci log / 'jig rten thams cad ston par byed/ /
ji snyed 'jig rten brda yod pa/ / de dag thams cad brtags pa ste; ; chos nyid de ni nam du yang / / chos gcig la yang mi gnas so/ /
rkyen rnams la ni rten bcas te/ / chos rnams so sor rab tu 'byung / / de dag ldog par de bzhin 'gyur; ; phyi ma ji bzhin sngon de bzhin/ /

This is the realm of the learned Who delight in ultimate peace. I will explain for you; Now please listen clearly.
Analyze the body within: Who herein is the “self”? Who can understand this way Will comprehend the existence or not of the self.
This body is a temporary set-up And has no place of abode; Who understands this body Will have no attachment to it.
Considering the body carefully, Everything will be clearly seen: Knowing all the elements are unreal, One will not create mental fabrications.
Based on whom does life arise, And based on whom does it disappear? Like a turning wheel of fire, Its beginning and end can’t be known.
The wise can observe with insight The impermanence of all existents; All things are empty and selfless, Forever apart from all signs.
All consequences are born from actions; Like dreams, they’re not truly real. From moment to moment they continually die away, The same as before and after.
Of all things seen in the world Only mind is the host; By grasping forms according to interpretation It becomes deluded, not true to reality.
All philosophies in the world Are mental fabrications; There has never been a single doctrine By which one could enter the true essence of things.
By the power of perceiver and perceived All kinds of things are born; They soon pass away, not staying, Dying out instant to instant.

Then Manjushri asked Chief of the Precious, “All sentient beings equally have four gross physical elements, with no self and nothing pertaining to self—how come there is the experience of pain and pleasure, beauty and ugliness, internal and external goodness, little sensation and much sensation? Why do some experience consequences in the present, and some in the future? And all this while there is no good or bad in the realm of reality.” Chief of the Precious answered in verse:

ji ltar las rnams byas gyur pa/ / tshor ba de bzhin 'byung 'gyur gyi/ / 'di la byed pa gang yang med/ / 'di ni sangs rgyas bstan pa'o/ /
shin tu phyis pa'i me long la/ / de ni ji ltar 'dug pa bzhin/ / de la de ni de bzhin snang / / chos kyi rang bzhin de bzhin no/ /

According to what deeds are done Do their resulting consequences come to be; Yet the doer has no existence: This is the Buddha’s teaching.
Like a clear mirror, According to what comes before it, Reflecting forms, each different, So is the nature of actions.
ji ltar zhing dang sa bon dag / gcig gis gcig ni mi shes kyang / / rang bzhin nye bar ston par byed/ / las kyi rang bzhin de bzhin no/ /

sgyu ma byed pa mkhas pa zhig / lam po cher ni song 'dug ste/ / gzugs rnams ston par byed pa bzhin/ / las kyi rang bzhin de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar shing gi 'khrul 'khor rnams/ / sna tshogs sgra mang rjod byed kyang / / de ni bdag dang bdag med min/ / las kyi rang bzhin de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar bya rnams mang po yi/ / sgo nga'i sbubs ni phye ba las/ / sgra skad gzhan dang gzhan 'gyur ba/ / las kyi rang bzhin de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar ma yi mngal du yang / / bu ni 'pho bar mi 'gyur te/ / 'on kyang dbang po sna tshogs 'gyur/ / las kyi rang bzhin de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar sems dmyal 'jigs pa na/ / gshin rje'i ris gtogs sdug bsngal ba/ / de dag la ni 'ong ba med/ / las kyi rang bzhin de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar rin chen mchog rnams dang / / lha yi bu rnams kun ldan yang / / 'pho bar snang ba gang yang med/ / de bzhin las kyi rang bzhin no/ /
ji ltar 'jig rten la la dag / bsam gyis mi khyab 'bar gyur kyang / / de dag 'ong ba gang yang med/ / las kyi rang bzhin de bzhin no/ /

And like a skillful magician Standing at a crossroads Causing many forms to appear, So is the nature of actions.
Like a mechanical robot Able to utter various sounds, Neither self nor not self: So is the nature of actions.
And like different species of birds All emerging from eggs, Yet their voices not the same: So is the nature of actions.
Just as in the womb All organs are developed, Their substance and features coming from nowhere: So is the nature of actions.
Also like being in hell— The various painful things All come from nowhere: So is the nature of actions.
Also like the sovereign king With seven supreme treasures— Their provenance cannot be found: So is the nature of actions.
And as when the various worlds Are burnt by a great conflagration, This fire comes from nowhere: So does the nature of actions.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras dag/ de bzhin gshegs pas chos gcig mngon par sangs rgyas na/ 'on kyang chos tshad med pa yang yang dag par ston zhing tshad med pa yang rnam par ston/ sems can tshad med pa yang rab tu ston/ gsung tshad med pa yang shin tu sgrog /sku tshad med pa yang shin tu ston/ bsam pa tshad med pa yang thugs su chud/ rdzu 'phrul tshad med pa yang yang dag par ston/ 'jig rten gyi khams tshad med pa yang shin tu skyong / rgyan tshad med pa yang byin gyis rlob; spyod yul tshad med pa yang shin tu ston la/ chos kyi dbyings kyang rnam pa tha dad du mi snang ba 'di ci zhig/
de nas byang chub sems dpa' yon tan dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

Then Manjushri asked Chief of the Virtuous, “Since that which the Buddhas realize is but one truth, how is it that they expound countless teachings, manifest countless lands, edify countless beings, speak in countless languages, appear in countless bodies, know countless minds, demonstrate countless mystic powers, are able to shake countless worlds, display countless extraordinary adornments, reveal boundless different realms of objects, whereas in the essential nature of things these different characteristics cannot be found at all?” Chief of the Virtuous answered in verse:

gnas 'di shes par dka' ba ste/ / rgyal ba'i sras kyis bdag la dris/ / de ni mkhas pas rnam par shes/ / yon tan mos pa dpyod par byed/ /
ji ltar sa ni gcig pu yang / / sems can mang po rab tu rgyu/ / de la gcig dang tha dad med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar me ni gcig pu yang / / 'jig rten kun na kun kyang 'bud/ / de la me lce tha dad med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar rgya mtsho gcig pu las/ / chu klung tshad med 'bab gyur kyang / / de la chu yi bye brag med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar rlung ni gcig pu yang / / 'jig rten kun tu rgyu zhing ldang / / de la gcig dang tha dad med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
sprin chen rnams ni 'brug bsgrags shing / / sa rnams kun kyang ngoms par byed/ / de yi char la bye brag med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar sa ni gcig pu yang / / myu gu sna tshogs 'byin cing ston/ / sa la bye brag 'byed pa med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar sgrib med nyi ma ni; ; phyogs bcu kun na snang bar byed/ / de la 'od zer tha dad med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar nam mkha'i zla ba ni/ / 'jig rten kun la rab tu snang / / gnas nas 'gyur ba gang yang med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar tshangs pa mi mjed bdag / stong gsum na ni 'dug mod kyi/ / de la lus ni bye brag med/ / sangs rgyas chos nyid de bzhin no/ /

The meaning of what you ask Is deep and hard to fathom. The wise are able to know it, Always delighting in Buddha’s virtues.
Just as the nature of earth is one While beings each live separately, And the earth has no thought of oneness or difference, So is the truth of all Buddhas.
Just as the nature of fire is one, While able to burn all things And the flames make no distinction, So is the truth of all Buddhas.
Just as the ocean is one With millions of different waves Yet the water is no different: So is the truth of all Buddhas.
And as the nature of wind is one While able to blow on all things And wind has no thought of oneness or difference: So is the truth of all Buddhas.
Also like great thunderheads Raining all over the earth, The raindrops make no distinctions: So is the truth of all Buddhas.
Just as the element earth, while one, Can produce various sprouts, Yet it’s not that the earth is diverse: So is the truth of all Buddhas.
Just as the sun without clouds overcast Shines throughout the ten directions, Its light beams having no difference: So is the truth of all Buddhas.
And just as the moon in the sky Is seen by all in the world Yet the moon doesn’t go to them: So is the truth of all Buddhas.
Just as the king of the gods Appears throughout the universe Yet his body has no change: So is the truth of all Buddhas.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' mig gi dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa la dge ba bskyed par gcig kyang de bzhin gshegs pa la dge ba'i rtsa ba bskyed pa'i sems can rnams gzugs sna tshogs dang / kha dog sna tshogs dang / rigs sna tshogs dang / dbang po sna tshogs dang / longs spyod sna tshogs dang / dbang sna tshogs dang / 'khor sna tshogs dang / phyug dbul sna tshogs dang / yon tan sna tshogs dang / shes rab sna tshogs su'ang snang la/ de bzhin gshegs pa ni/ gang la'ang mi mnyam pa'am, tha dad du dgongs pa gang yang med na 'di ci zhig/
de nas byang chub sems dpa' mig gi dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

Then Manjushri asked the enlightening being Chef in Vision, “Buddhas as fields of blessings are one and the same to all—how is it that when sentient beings give alms to them, the resulting rewards are not the same—various forms, various families, various faculties, various property, various masters, various followers, various official positions, various virtuous qualities, various kinds of knowledge—and yet the Buddhas are impartial toward them, not thinking of them as different?” Chief in Vision answered in verse:

ji ltar sa ni ro gcig kyang / / sa bon tshul bzhin myu gu ston/ / byams dang sdang bar sems pa med/ / sangs rgyas yon phul de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar chu ni ro gcig kyang / / snod kyi dbang gis rnam par 'gyur/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas yon phul ba/ / rgyud kyi rnams la rnam par 'gyur/ /
ji ltar sgyu mkhan mkhas pa ni/ / rtag tu 'khor kyang mgu bar byed/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas yon phul ba/ / shin tu sbyangs pa dga' bar byed/ /
ji ltar mkhas pa'i rgyal po dag / 'gro ba mang po shes par byed/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas yon phul ba/ / ji ltar bskyed bzhin shes par byed/ /
ji ltar dri med me long la/ / ci 'dra'i gzugs rnams de bzhin snang / / de bzhin sems can bsam tshul du/ / sangs rgyas yon phul rnam dag 'gyur/ /
ji ltar dug phan sman gyi rnams/ / dug nad thams cad sos par byed/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas yon phul ba/ / nyon mongs dug ni chen po sel/ /
ji ltar nyi ma shar ba ni/ / 'gro ba 'di dag snang bar byed/ / mun pa dag kyang rnam par sel/ / sangs rgyas yon phul de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar zla ba dri med pa/ / kun tu mnyam pa nyid byas te/ / sa ni rab tu snang bar byed/ / sangs rgyas yon phul de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar chu yi stobs shugs kyis/ / sa ri thams cad g.yo 'gyur ba/ / sangs rgyas yon phul de bzhin du/ / srid gsum 'khor ba rnams kyang skyong / /
'bar dang 'od 'phro bcas pa'i me/ / thams cad dag tu sreg pa'i dngos/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas yon phul ba/ / 'du byed thams cad sreg par byed/ /

Just as the earth is one Yet produces sprouts according to the seeds Without partiality toward any of them, So is the Buddhas’ field of blessings.
And just as water is uniform Yet differs in shape according to the vessel, So is the Buddhas’ field of blessings: It differs only due to beings’ minds.
And just as a skilled magician Can make people happy, So can the Buddhas’ field of blessings Cause sentient beings joy.
As a king with wealth and knowledge Can bring gladness to the masses, So can Buddhas’ field of blessings Bring peace and happiness to all.
Like a clear mirror Reflecting images according to the forms, So from Buddhas’ field of blessings Rewards are obtained according to one’s heart.
Like a panacea Which can cure all poisoning, So does Buddhas’ field of blessings Annihilate all afflictions.
And just as when the sun comes up It illuminates the world, Thus does Buddhas’ field of blessings Clear away all darkness.
Like the clear full moon Shining over the earth, So is Buddhas’ field of blessings Equal in all places.
Just as a great conflagration Can burn up all things, So does Buddhas’ field of blessings Burn up all fabrication.
Just as a violent wind Can cause the earth to tremble, So does Buddhas’ field of blessings Move all living beings.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' brtson 'grus dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa gcig na/ thams cad lta ba mthun pas nyon mongs pa thams cad spong bar ci'i phyir mi 'gyur/ de dag kun la yang gzugs ni/ gzugs nyid du zad/ tshor ba yang tshor ba nyid du zad/ 'du shes kyang 'du shes nyid du zad/ 'du byed rnams kyang 'du byed rnams nyid du zad/ rnam par shes pa yang rnam par shes pa nyid du zad/ 'dod pa'i khams kyang 'dod pa'i khams nyid du zad/ gzugs kyi khams kyang gzugs kyi khams nyid du zad/ gzugs med pa'i khams kyang gzugs med pa'i khams nyid du zad/ ma rig pa yang ma rig pa nyid du zad/ sred pa yang sred pa nyid du zad la/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i bstan pa yang phan par byed pa'am/ gnod par byed pa ma yin na/ de ci'i phyir/
de nas byang chub sems dpa' brtson 'grus dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

Then Manjushri asked Chief in Effort, “The Buddhas’ teaching is one, which all beings can see—why don’t they all immediately cut off all the bonds of afflictions and win emancipation? Furthermore, in their clusters of material form, clusters of sensation, conception, coordination-activity, and consciousness, the realms of desire, form, and formlessness, as well as ignorance and craving, they are no different—this is the Buddha’s teaching; why is it of benefit to some and not to others?” chief in Effort answered in verse:

de ltar khyod kyis gang dris pa/ / la la myur du rnam grol zhing / / la la dka' bar 'grol 'gyur ba/ / sangs rgyas sras po bdag la nyon/ /
'di ni dpag tu med pa yi/ / sangs rgyas bstan gyi nyes ma yin/ / dad dang brtson 'grus nan tan gyis/ / rtag tu khyad par 'gyur ba yin/ /
ji ltar rtsa dang shing gsher ba/ / mer bcug shin tu nyam chung zhing / / ring por mi thogs 'chi bar 'gyur/ / de bzhin le lo bstan pa la/ /
ji ltar gtsubs nas gtsubs pa'i tshe; ; ma byung ba ni myur bteg na/ / myur du 'chi bar 'gyur ba bzhin/ / de ltar le lo bstan pa la/ /
nyi ma'i nor bu lci ba la/ / yang dang yang bzhag bteg pa ni/ / de la me 'byung mi 'gyur te/ / de bzhin le lo bstan pa la/ /
ji ltar nyi ma shar ba'i tshe/ / byis pa rnams ni mig btsums shing / / mi mthong ci phyir zhes smra ba/ / de bzhin le lo bstan pa la; ;
rkang lag med par skyes pa'i mi/ / ji ltar smyig mnga' kha bug gis/ / sa ni dbug par 'dod pa bzhin/ / de ltar le lo bstan pa la/ /
ji ltar byis pas rgya mtsho las/ / yang dang yang du bcus byas shing / / skam par la la 'dod pa ltar/ / de bzhin le lo bstan pa la/ /
ji ltar bum pa chus bkang bzhin/ / bskal pa'i me ni byung ba'i tshe/ / la la gsad par 'dod pa ltar/ / de bzhin le lo bstan pa la/ /
ji ltar la la phyogs bcu yi/ / nam mkha' ji snyed tha mal pa'i/ / gzugs kyis rgyas par dgang smra ba/ / de bzhin le lo bstan pa la/ /

Listen well and clearly And I will answer truly. Some are quickly freed, And some can hardly escape.
If one wishes to eliminate The countless faults and ills, One should work with diligence On the Buddha-teaching.
For example, a little bit of fire Moisture in the kindling will extinguish; So it is with those who’re lazy About the Buddha-teaching.
Just as when you drill for fire And stop before the fire appears The heat will immediately disappear: So it is with the indolent.
When a man with a magnifying glass Doesn’t focus the sun’s rays on anything, Fire can never be obtained: So it is with the lazy.
Like when the dazzling sun shines A child shuts its eyes And complains “Why can’t I see?”: So too are the lazy like this.
Like a man lacking hands and feet Wanting to shoot all over the earth With arrows made of reeds: So too are the lazy ones.
Like using a single hair To take the ocean water Trying to drain the ocean: So also are the slothful.
Like when the eon fire flares Trying to put it out with a little water: So are those who are lazy About the Buddha’s teaching.
Like someone who sees space While sitting still, unmoving, And says he is traveling through it: So is the lazy one.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' chos dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras/ chos kyi tshul nyon mongs pa thams cad skem pa 'di nyid blangs kyang sems can la la 'dod chags kyi dbang du 'gro/ la la zhe sdang gi dbang du 'gro/ la la gti mug gi dbang du 'gro/ nga rgyal gyi dbang du 'gro/ 'chab pa'i dbang du 'gro/ 'khon du 'dzin pa'i dbang du 'gro/ phrag dog gi dbang du 'gro /ser sna'i dbang du 'gro /sgyu'i dbang du 'gro zhing / g.yo'i dbang du 'gro la/ chos de dag kyang sems med par gzung du yang mi nus te/ nyon mongs par gdags pa kun gyi rnam pa kun tu sems kyi rgyud du zad na/ de ji lta bu/
de nas byang chub sems dpa' chos dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

Then Manjushri asked Chief in Doctrine, “According to what the Buddha says, if any sentient beings accept and hold the true teaching, they can cut off all afflictions. Why then are there those who accept and hold the true teaching and yet do not cut off afflictions, who go along with anger and resentment, go along with jealousy and stinginess, go along with deception and flattery, compelled by the power of these things, having no will to detach from them? If they are able to accept and hold the true teaching, why then do they still produce afflictions in their mental actions?” Chief in Doctrine answered in verse:

gang gi don du dris pa rnams/ / sangs rgyas sras po nga las nyon/ / yang dag sangs rgyas bstan pa 'di/ / thos pa tsam gyis mi 'grub bo/ /
la la stobs med chu klung gis/ / nad kyis khyer bar gyur pa dag / skom zhing shi bar gyur pa bzhin/ / ma bsgoms chos kyang de bzhin no/ /

Listen well and clearly To the true meaning of what you ask. It is not only by much learning That one can enter the Buddhas’ teaching.
Like a man floating in water Who dies of thirst, afraid of drowning: So are those who are learned Who do not apply the teaching.
ji ltar 'gro ba mang po la/ / zas dang skom dag sbyin byas kyang / / bdag nyid bkres pas shi ba ltar/ / de bzhin chos la ma bsgoms pa'o/ /

ji ltar sman pa la la zhig / sman rnams thams cad bdog bzhin du/ / lto yi nad kyis shi ba bzhin/ / chos la ma bsgoms de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar dbyig gi mdzod dag tu/ / rin chen mang po bgrang byed kyang / / nam phyed tsam yang mi 'thob pa/ / chos la ma bsgoms de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar bde ba kun ldan pa'i/ / rgyal po'i pho brang 'khor skyes kyang / / zas dang skom dag mi bdog pa/ / de bzhin chos la ma bsgoms pa'o/ /
ji ltar 'on pa rol mo yi/ / sil snyan glu la mkhas pa zhig / gzhan dag de yis dga' byed pa/ / chos la ma bsgoms de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar dmus long ri mo mkhan/ / tshong dus dbus su 'brir 'jug kyang / / bdag nyid kyis ni mi mthong ba/ / chos la ma bsgoms de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar mtsho chen mnyan pa zhig / skye bo mang po sgrol byed kyang / / bdag nyid de nang 'chi 'gyur ba/ / chos la ma bsgoms de bzhin no/ /
ji ltar lam gyi bzhi mdor yang / / phun sum tshogs pa kun brjod cing / / bdag gis thob par mi 'gyur ba/ / chos la ma bsgoms de bzhin no/ /

Like a person skilled in medicine Who can’t cure his own disease: So are those who are learned But do not apply the teaching.
Like someone counting others’ treasures Without half a coin of his own: So is the one who is learned Who doesn’t practice the teaching.
Like one who’s born in a royal palace Yet who freezes and starves: So are those who are learned But do not practice the teaching.
Like a deaf musician Who pleases others, not hearing himself: So is the one who is learned Who does not apply the teaching.
Like a blind embroiderer Who shows others but cannot see: So are those who are learned But do not practice the teaching.
Like a ship’s captain Who dies at sea: So are those who are learned But do not apply the teaching.
Like someone on a corner Saying all kinds of fine things, While having no real inner virtue: So are those who don’t practice.

Then Manjushri asked Chief in Knowledge, “In the Buddha teaching, knowledge is chief—so why do the Buddhas, in dealing with people, sometimes praise generosity, sometimes praise self-control, sometimes praise tolerance, sometimes praise effort, sometimes praise meditation, sometimes praise wisdom, or again sometimes praise kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, yet all the while there is ultimately but one truth whereby to attain emancipation and realize complete perfect enlightenment?” Chief in Knowledge answered in verse:

sems can gzhan gyi bsam shes pa/ / ngo mtshar rmad du byung ba ste/ / de ltar gang gi don dris pa/ / sangs rgyas sras po bdag las nyon/ /
smra ba'i mchog ni gang yang rung / / chos gcig gis ni byung ba med/ / gang yang 'byung ba yod pa min/ / 'byung bar 'gyur ba de bzhin med/ /
skal pa gang la gnas pa yi/ / bsam pa mkhyen nas don mdzad cing / / gang la ci dag tshul mthun pa/ / de bzhin chos kyang bstan pa mdzad/ /
ser sna can la sbyin pa brjod/ / tshul khrims ngan la tshul khrims rnams/ / mi bzod la ni bzod dang des/ / brtson 'grus 'byor pa le lo la'o/ /
rnam par 'khrugs la bsam gtan brjod/ / shes rab 'byor ba shes med la'o/ / gdug pa'i sems la byams pa bshad/ / 'tshe ba rnams la snying rje ste/ /
zhum pa la ni dga' ba bshad/ / 'khor ba'i sems la btang snyoms te/ / sangs rgyas chos rnams thams cad kyang / / rim pas de ltar 'byung ba yin/ /
ji ltar sa la las bya ba/ / khyim gyi dngos la rim pa yin/ / de bzhin sbyin pa tshul khrims dag / byang chub sems dpa'i thog mar 'gro /
rgyal ba'i gnas dang grong rdal rnams/ / rub pa'i phyir ni ra ba ste/ / de bzhin bzod pa brtson 'grus dag / byang chub sems dpa' rub phyir ro/ /

Son of Buddha, most rare Is the ability to know beings’ minds. As for what you ask, Listen well and I’ll explain.
Of the past, future, And present guides, None expounds just one method To become enlightened.
Buddhas know beings’ minds, Their natures each different; According to what they need to be freed, Thus do the Buddhas teach.
To the stingy they praise giving, To the immoral they praise ethics; To the angry they praise tolerance, To the lazy they praise effort.
To those with scattered minds they praise meditative concentration, To the ignorant, they praise wisdom; To the inhuman, they praise kindness and sympathy, To the malicious, compassion.
To the troubled they praise joy, To the devious they praise equanimity. Thus practicing step-by-step, One gradually fulfills all Buddha teachings.
It’s like first setting up a foundation Then building the room: Generosity and self-control, like this, Are bases of enlightening beings’ practices.
Just like building a castle To protect all the people: So are tolerance and effort Protecting enlightening beings.
ji ltar gdugs gcig rgyal po ni/ / sa rnams thams cad skyong bar byed/ / de bzhin bsam gtan shes rab dag / byang chub sems dpa'i skyabs bzhin no/ /
'khor los bsgyur ba'i rgyal po ni/ / bde ba thams cad ster ba ltar/ / de bzhin tshangs pa'i gnas rnams kyang / / byang chub sems dpa'i bde ba 'byin/ /
And just as a universal monarch Can bestow all felicities: So can kindness, compassion, joy and equanimity Give enlightening beings happiness.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' bzang po'i dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras/ de ste sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi 'byung ba gcig na/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing rnams na sbyor ba rnam pa tha dad pa dag 'di ltar 'jig rten gyi khams rnam pa tha dad pa dang / chos bstan pa rnam pa tha dad pa dang / sems can 'dul ba rnam pa tha dad pa dang / tshe'i tshad rnam pa tha dad pa dang / 'od kyi dkyil 'khor rnam pa tha dad pa dang / rdzu 'phrul dang rnam par 'phrul pa rnam pa tha dad pa dang / 'khor tshogs pa rnam pa tha dad pa dang / bstan pa'i tshul rnam pa tha dad pa dang / chos kyi byin gyi rlabs rnam pa tha dad pa dag ci'i phyir snang bar gyur/ sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad yongs su ma rdzogs par ni/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub mngon par 'tshang rgya bar mi nus so/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' bzang po'i dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

Then Manjushri asked Chief in Goodness, “The Buddhas, the World Honored Ones, attain emancipation by means of one path alone; why then are the things in the Buddha-lands we see now various and not the same? That is to say, the worlds, the realms of beings, the teaching and training, the life span and auras of light, the miracles, the congregations, the modes of teaching and doctrinal bases, each have differences, yet all include all the truths of the Buddhas, whereby complete perfect enlightement is attained.” Chief in Goodness answered in verse:

chos kyi rgyal po'i chos nyid ni; ; 'jam dpal rtag tu gcig pa ste/ / bsgribs pa med pa gzigs pa yi/ / 'byung ba de yang gcig pu 'o/ /
sangs rgyas thams cad sku gcig ste/ / de bzhin gshegs pa chos kyi sku; ; shes rab thugs kyang gcig pa ste/ / mi 'jigs stobs kyang de bzhin no/ /
sngon chad byang chub zhugs pa'i tshe/ / ji ltar yongs su bsngo mdzad pa/ / 'khor du chos rnams bstan pa dang / / de dag zhing yang de bzhin 'gyur/ /
zhing gi phun sum gang yod pa/ / sangs rgyas rnams la thams cad 'grub/ / sems can ji ltar sbyangs pa rnams/ / de yi rnam pa de ltar mthong / /
ji ltar sangs rgyas chos nyid du/ / kun gyis sangs rgyas mi mthong ste/ / sangs rgyas zhing dang sku dag dang / / 'khor du chos bstan de bzhin no/ /
gang rnam smon lam mthun ldan zhing / / sngon chad bsam pa yongs sbyangs pas/ / thams cad gzigs pa'i tshul gyi rnams/ / ji lta ba bzhin thams cad mthong / /
sems can bsam pa ji bzhin dang / / las dang stobs kyang ji bzhin pa/ / de lta de ltar mthong 'gyur te/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi rnam 'phrul lo/ /
sangs rgyas zhing la rtog mi mnga'/ / de dag byams sdang yod pa min/ / bsam pa'i tshul ni ji bzhin du/ / srog chags rnams kyis de bzhin mthong / /
rnam pa tha dad 'jig rten khams/ / de ltar snang bar gyur pa de; ; drang srong chen po kun gzigs pa'i/ / nyes pa'i skyon las gyur pa med/ /
gang na 'dul ba yod pa yi/ / 'jig rten khams rnams thams cad du/ / skyes bu drang srong rnams kyang snang / / de ni sangs rgyas chos nyid do/ /

Manjushri, truth is always thus: The Kings of Truth have just one truth. People unhindered by anything, They leave birth and death by one road.
All the Buddha bodies Are just one reality-body: One in mind, one in wisdom, The same in power and fearlessness.
According to their dedications When originally starting out for enlightenment, They developed such lands, Congregations, and teachings.
The adornments of all buddha-lands Are totally complete; According to differences in beings’ actions They seem to be unalike.
The buddha-lands and buddha-bodies, The congregations and explanations: Such Buddhist teachings as these No sentient beings can see.
When their minds are purified And their vows fulfilled, Such illuminated people Then are able to see.
According to beings’ mental inclinations And the force of the fruits of their deeds, There seem to them to be differences; This is due to Buddhas’ mystic powers.
Buddha-lands have no discrimination, No hatred and no attachment: But according to beings’ minds They seem to have differences.
Because of this, in the worlds What is seen is different: This is not the fault Of the enlightened sages.
In all worlds Those who are fit to receive the teaching Always see the Hero of humanity: Such is the Buddhas’ teaching.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras/ bdag cag gis rang rang gi spobs pa bstan pa rnams smras pa yin na/ da khyod kyis sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi yul las brtsams te spobs par gyis shig /sangs rgyas kyi yul gyi yul ni/ gang / sangs rgyas kyi yul gyi tshogs ni/ gang / sangs rgyas kyi yul du 'gro ba ni/ gang / sangs rgyas kyi yul la 'jug pa ni/ ji lta bu/ sangs rgyas kyi yul khong du chud pa'i shes pa ni/ gang / sangs rgyas kyi yul gyi rjes su 'gro ba ni/ gang / sangs rgyas kyi yul shin tu bstan pa ni/ gang / sangs rgyas kyi yul shes par byed pa ni/ gang / sangs rgyas kyi yul rtogs pa ni/ gang / sangs rgyas kyi yul gyi tshul ni/ ji lta bu/ sangs rgyas kyi yul ni/ ji tsam du yangs/
de nas byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad la tshigs su bcad de smras pa/

Then these enlightening beings said to Manjushri, “Son of Buddha, we have each spoken of our understanding. We ask you, benevolent one, to use your wonderful powers of elucidation to expound the realm of the enlightened—what is the sphere of the Buddhas, what are the causal bases of the sphere of the Buddhas, what are the methods of liberation in the sphere of the Buddhas, what are the entries into the states of the Buddhas, what is the wisdom in the realm of the Buddhas, what are the laws of the realm of the Buddhas, what are the explanations of the states of the Buddhas, what is the knowledge of the sphere of the Buddhas, what is the realization of the realm of the Buddhas, what are the manifestations of the states of the Buddhas, what is the extent of the sphere of the Buddhas?” Manjushri answered in verse:

nam mkha'i yul dang 'dra ba ste/ / kun tu 'od la 'dra ba med/ / sems can thams cad 'jug pa ste/ / chos nyid la ni 'jug pa med/ /
tshogs rnams thams cad bstan par ni/ / bskal pa bye bar mi nus te/ / ji snyed rgyal ba'i tshogs mnga' ba/ / de ni sangs rgyas yul yin no/ /
blo gros sems kyang de bzhin du/ / sems can thams cad rab tu 'jug / de la bstan pa thogs pa med/ / de ni sangs rgyas yul yin no/ /
'jig rten thams cad 'jug pa dang / / 'jig rten rgyu ba gang yod pa/ / de dag kun la ye shes gnas/ / gzugs su snang ba ma yin no/ /
sangs rgyas ye shes chags med de/ / dus gsum kun la chags pa med/ / nam mkha' 'byung dang mtshungs pa yin/ / de ni ye shes yul yin no/ /
chos kyi dbyings ni tha mi dad/ / sems can khams rnams rtogs par mkhyen/ / dbyings rnams thams cad rab tu brnyes/ / de ni sangs rgyas yul yin no/ /
sgrar gdags ji snyed yod pa dang / / sems can kun gyi sgra skad du; ; sgra la mkhyen pa thugs chud kyang / / rnam par rtog pa gang yang med/ /
rnam shes rnam par shes bya med/ / sems kyis brjod pa'ang ma yin te/ / ye shes rang bzhin shin tu dag / sems can rnams la'ang rab tu bshad/ /
nyon mongs med cing las med de/ / dngos po med cing gnas pa med/ / snang ba med cing rgyu ba med/ / 'jig rten dag tu'ang mnyam par spyod/ /
sems can kun gyi sems kyi rnams/ / dus gsum kun tu rab yangs pa/ / sems gcig la ni rab 'jug pas/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi ye shes 'jug/

The profound realm of the Buddhas Is equal in extent to space; All beings enter it, Yet really nothing’s entered.
The sublime causes Of the Buddhas’ profound states Could not be fully told In a billion eons of talk.
According to beings’ minds and wisdom, Buddhas lead them on and aid them; This is the realm of the Buddhas, Liberating beings this way.
Able to enter all lands In the world, The body of knowledge is formless And cannot be seen by others.
The Buddhas’ knowledge is free, Unhindered in all times; This realm of wisdom Is equanimous as space.
The realms of beings of the cosmos Ultimately have no distinction; Thoroughly knowing all of them Is the sphere of the enlightened ones.
All languages and sounds There are in the worlds Buddhas’ knowledge can comprehend Without discrimination.
Not perceptible to sense consciousness And not the sphere of mind, Its nature fundamentally pure, Buddhas’ knowledge teaches living beings.
Not action, not affliction, With no thing and no abode, No looking and no object, Their realization’s equanimous throughout the world.
The minds of all sentient beings In the past, present, and future, The enlightened, in one instant, Can thoroughly comprehend.

de nas de'i tshe 'jig rten gyi khams de dag na sems can gyi rgyud ji snyed pa dang / chos kyi rgyud ji snyed pa dang / las kyi rgyud ji snyed pa dang / 'jig rten gyi rgyud ji snyed pa dang / lus kyi rgyud ji snyed pa dang / dbang po'i rgyud ji snyed pa dang / skye ba'i rgyud ji snyed pa dang / tshul khrims kyi 'bras bu'i rgyud ji snyed pa dang; tshul khrims log pa'i 'bras bu'i rgyud ji snyed pa dang / yul gyi 'bras bu'i rgyud ji snyed pa de dag thams cad sangs rgyas kyi mthus rab tu snang bar gyur te/ ji ltar 'jig rten gyi khams de dag tu rab tu snang bar gyur pa de bzhin du shar phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong tshad med pa/ dpag tu med pa/ grangs med pa; bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ mtshungs pa med pa/ kun tu mtha' yas pa/ mu med pa/ sa mtshams med pa/ gzhal du med pa/ brjod du med pa/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa; nam mkha'i dbyings kyi mthas gtugs pa thams cad na yang sems can gyi rgyud ji snyed pa zhes bya ba nas gzhung de bzhin du yul gyi 'bras bu'i rgyud ji snyed pa'i bar du de dag thams cad sangs rgyas kyi mthus rab tu snang bar gyur to/ / de bzhin du lho phyogs dang / de bzhin du nub phyogs dang / de bzhin du byang phyogs dang / de bzhin du byang shar gyi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du shar lho'i phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du lho nub kyi phyogs mtshams dang / de bzhin du nub byang gi phyogs mtshams dang; de bzhin du 'og gi phyogs dang / de bzhin du steng gi phyogs kyi 'jig rten gyi khams bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong tshad med/ dpag tu med pa/ grangs med pa/ bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ mtshungs pa med pa/ kun tu mtha' yas pa/ mu med pa/ sa mtshams med pa/ gzhal du med pa/ brjod du med pa/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa/ nam mkha'i dbyings kyi mthas gtugs pa dag na sems can gyi rgyud ji snyed pa zhes bya ba nas gzhung de bzhin du yul gyi 'bras bu'i rgyud ji snyed pa'i bar du de dag thams cad sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis rab tu snang bar gyur to/ /

Then all the differences in state, activity, realm, body, faculties, birth, results of keeping precepts, results of breaking precepts, and in resulting lands of all sentient beings in this world Endurance, by the Buddha’s spiritual power all became clearly manifest. In the same way all these various differences of all sentient beings in the infinite worlds throughout the space of the cosmos in all directions were all clearly revealed by the Buddha’s mystic power.
shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ byang chub sems dpa' dris pa snang ba zhes bya ba'i le'u ste/ bco lnga pa'o// //
[16. spyod yul yongs su dag pa'i le'u]
BOOK ELEVEN. Purifying Practice
bam po bco brgyad pa/

de nas byang chub sems dpa' ye shes dpal gyis byang chub sems dpa' 'jam dpal la 'di skad ces smras so/ /
kye rgyal ba'i sras/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams ji ltar na kha na ma tho ba med pa'i lus kyi las dang ldan pa yi/ kha na ma tho ba med pa'i ngag gi las dang ldan pa yin/ kha na ma tho ba med pa'i yid kyi las dang ldan pa yin/ lus kyi las rnam par ma nyams pa yin/ ngag gi las rnam par ma nyams pa yin; yid kyi las rnam par ma nyams pa yin/ lus kyi las ma smad pa yin/ ngag gi las ma smad pa yin/ yid kyi las ma smad pa yin/ lus kyi las mi 'phrog pa yin; ngag gi las mi 'phrog pa yin/ yid kyi las mi 'phrog pa yin/ lus kyi las mi zlog pa yin/ ngag gi las mi zlog pa yin/ yid kyi las mi zlog pa yin/ lus kyi las mi 'khrugs pa yin/ ngag gi las mi 'khrugs pa yin/ yid kyi las mi 'khrugs pa yin/ lus kyi las bsngags pa yin/ ngag gi las bsngags pa yin/ yid kyi las bsngags pa yin/ lus kyi las rnam par dag pa yin/ ngag gi las rnam par dag pa yin/ yid kyi las rnam par dag pa yin/ lus kyi las nye bar nyon mongs pa med pa yin; ngag gi las nye bar nyon mongs pa med pa yin/ yid kyi las nye bar nyon mongs pa med pa yin/ lus kyi las ye shes sngon du 'gro ba yin/ ngag gi las ye shes sngon du 'gro ba yin/ yid kyi las ye shes sngon du 'gro ba yin/ rigs phun sum tshogs pa yin/ rus phun sum tshogs pa yin/ rgyud phun sum tshogs pa yin/ gzugs phun sum tshogs pa yin/ mtshan phun sum tshogs pa yin/ dran pa phun sum tshogs pa yin/ blo gros phun sum tshogs pa yin/ rtogs pa phun sum tshogs pa yin/ dga' ba phun sum tshogs pa yin/ blo phun sum tshogs pa yin/ blo gros mchog tu gyur pa yin/ blo gros dam par gyur pa yin/ blo gros rab tu gyur pa yin/ blo gros tshad med pa yin/ blo gros grangs med pa yin/ blo gros bsam gyis mi khyab pa yin/ blo gros mtshungs pa med pa yin/ blo gros gzhal du med pa yin/ blo gros brjod du med pa yin/ rgyu'i stobs can yin/ bsam pa'i stobs can yin/ sbyor ba'i stobs can yin/ rkyen gyi stobs can yin/ dmigs pa'i stobs can yin/ dbang po'i stobs can yin/ rnam par lta ba'i stobs can yin/ zhi gnas kyi stobs can yin/ lhag mthong gi stobs can yin/ nges par rtogs pa'i stobs can yin/ phung po la mkhas pa yin/ khams la mkhas pa yin/ skye mched la mkhas pa yin/ rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba la mkhas pa yin/ 'dod pa'i khams la mkhas pa yin/ gzugs kyi khams la mkhas pa yin/ gzugs med pa'i khams la mkhas pa yin/ 'das pa la mkhas pa yin/ ma 'ongs pa la mkhas pa yin; da ltar byung ba la mkhas pa yin/ dran pa yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag la mkhas pa yin/ chos rnam par 'byed pa yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag la mkhas pa yin/ brtson 'grus yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag la mkhas pa yin/ dga' ba yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag la mkhas pa yin/ rab tu byang ba yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag la mkhas pa yin/ ting nge 'dzin yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag la mkhas pa yin/ btang snyoms yang dag byang chub kyi yan lag la mkhas pa yin/ stong pa nyid yongs su bsgoms pa yin/ mtshan ma med pa yongs su bsgoms pa yin/ smon pa med pa yongs su bsgoms pa yin/ sbyin pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ tshul khrims kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ bzod pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ brtson 'grus kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ bsam gtan gyi pha rol tu phyin pa yin; shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ byams pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ snying rje'i pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ dga' ba'i pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ btang snyoms kyi pha rol tu phyin pa yin/ gnas dang gnas ma yin pa shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin/ 'das pa dang / ma 'ongs pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i las kyi rnam par smin pa shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin/ dbang po dang / brtson 'grus tha dad pa yongs su rdzogs par bya ba gcig nas gcig tu brgyud pa khong du chud pa yin/ khams sna tshogs dang / khams du ma'i shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin/ mos pa sna tshogs dang / mos pa du ma shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin/ kun tu 'gro ba'i lam shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin/ bsam gtan dang / rnam par thar pa dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / snyoms par 'jug pa dang / kun nas nyon mongs pa dang / rnam par byang ba dang / ldang ba shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin; bsgribs pa med pa'i rjes su dran pa shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin/ lha'i mig chags pa med pa shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin/ bag chags kyi mtshams sbyor ba yang dag par bcad pa shes par bya ba khong du chud pa yin/ lha'i dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ klu'i dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin; gnod sbyin gyi dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ dri za'i dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ lha ma yin gyi dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ nam mkha' lding gi dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ mi'am ci'i dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ lto 'phye chen po'i dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ mi'i dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ tshangs pa'i dbang pos yongs su bzung ba yin/ lha'i dbang pos bkur ba yin/ klu'i dbang pos bkur ba yin/ gnod sbyin gyi dbang pos bkur ba yin; dri za'i dbang pos bkur ba yin/ lha ma yin gyi dbang pos bkur ba yin/ nam mkha'i lding gi dbang pos bkur ba yin/ mi'am ci'i dbang pos bkur ba yin; lto 'phye chen pos dbang pos bkur ba yin/ mi'i dbang pos bkur ba yin/ tshangs pa'i dbang pos bkur ba yin/ sems can thams cad kyi gnas su gyur pa yin; skyabs su gyur pa yin/ dpung gnyen du gyur pa yin/ mgon du gyur pa yin/ sgron mar gyur pa yin/ snang bar gyur pa yin/ 'od du gyur pa yin/ 'dren par gyur pa yin; rnam par 'dren par gyur pa yin/ yongs su 'dren par gyur pa yin/ sems can thams cad kyi mchog tu gyur pa yin/ gtso bor gyur pa yin/ thu bor gyur pa yin/ rab tu gyur pa yin/ dam par gyur pa yin/ phul du gyur pa yin/ bla na med pa yin/ kye rgyal ba'i sras/ ji ltar na/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams mnyam pa med pa yin/ de skad ces smras pa dang /

THEN THE ENLIGHTENING BEING Chief in Knowledge asked the enlightening being Manjushri, “How can enlightening beings attain faultless physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain harmless physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain blameless physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain invulnerable physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain nonregressive physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain unshakable physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain excellent physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain pure physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain unpolluted physical, verbal, and mental action? How can they attain physical, verbal, and mental action that is guided by wisdom? How can they attain birth in appropriate places, among good people, physically complete, with full mindfulness, understanding, completeness in conduct, fearlessness, and awareness? How can they attain excellent discernment, foremost discernment, supreme discernment, immeasurable discernment, incalculable discernment, inconceivable discernment, incomparable discernment, unfathomable discernment, inexpressible discernment? How can they attain causal power, will power, skill power, the power of proper conditions and objects of attention, faculty power, powers of observation, the power to stop the mind, powers of analytic insight, and power of contemplative thought? How can they attain skill in analyzing the psychophysical elements and organs, skill in analyzing interdependent origination, skill in analyzing the realms of desire, form, and formlessness, and skill in understanding the past, present, and future? How can they cultivate well the branches of enlightenment—mindfulness, discernment, effort, joy, well-being, concentration, relinquishment? How can they attain emptiness, signlessness, wishlessness? How can they fulfill the means of transcendence—generosity, self-control, tolerance, effort, meditation, and wisdom? How can they fulfill kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity? How can they attain the power of knowledge of what is so and what is not, the power of knowledge of consequences of past, future, and present acts, the power of knowledge of superiority and inferiority of faculties, the power of knowledge of various realms, the power of knowledge of various understandings, the power of knowledge of where all paths lead, the power of knowledge of defilement or purity of meditations, liberations, and trances, the power of knowledge of past lives, the power of knowledge of unhindered clairvoyance, and the power of knowledge of having cut off all taints? How can they always gain the protection, respect, and support of celestial kings, dragon kings, yaksha kings, gandharva kings, titan kings, garuda kings, kinnara kings, mahoraga kings, human kings, and brahma kings? How can they be a reliance and savior, a refuge and resort, a lamp and a light, an illuminator and a guide, a supreme and universal leader for all sentient beings? How can they be foremost and greatest, excellent and supreme, sublime and most wonderful, highest and unexcelled, incomparable and peerless among all sentient beings?”

Manjushri said to Chief in Knowledge, “Excellent, O Child of Buddha! You have asked this out of a desire to benefit many, to bring peace to many, out of pity for the world, to profit and gladden celestial and human beings. Child of Buddha, if enlightening beings use their minds properly, they can attain all supreme qualities, can have a mind unhindered in regard to all enlightening teachings, can remain on the Path of the Buddhas of past, present, and future, never leaving it even while living in the midst of sentient beings, can comprehend the characteristics of all things, cut off all evil and fulfill all good. They will be physically most excellent, like Universally Good; all of their practical vows they will be able to fulfill, and will be free in all ways, and will be guides for all sentient beings. How can they use their minds so as to attain all supreme sublime qualities?

'di la byang chub sems dpa' khyim gyi nang na 'dug pa'i tshe sems can thams cad rang bzhin shes pa dang ldan pas/ khyim gyi thibs pos zil gyis mi non par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
pha ma dang 'grogs pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad/ skye bo thams cad yongs su bskyab pa'i phyir sangs rgyas dang 'grogs par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
bu dang bu mo dang 'grogs pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad sred pa dang shin tu bral bas dga' ba dang / mi dga' ba dang / rnam par bral bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
'dod pa'i yon tan dang 'grogs pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad yon tan gyi pha rol tu phyin pas 'dod pa'i gsal shing rnam par sel bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
glu dang / gar dang / rol mo dang / sil snyan dang 'grogs pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad gar mkhan gyi tshon lta bur mthong ba dang ldan zhing chos yang dag par 'gro ba'i brjod pa rab tu thob par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

Enlightening beings at home Should wish that all beings Realize the nature of “home” is empty And escape its pressures.
While serving their parents, They should wish that all beings Serve the Buddha, Protecting and nourishing everyone.
While with their spouses and children, They should wish that all beings Be impartial toward everyone And forever give up attachment.
When attaining desires, They should wish that all beings Pull out the arrow of lust And realize ultimate peace.
On festive occasions They should wish that all beings Enjoy themselves with truth And realize amusement’s not real.

chung ma'i 'khor gyi nang na 'dug pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad 'dod pa'i gsal shing dang bral zhing / 'phags pa'i sar tshud par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
rgyan gyis brgyan pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad srid par 'byung ba 'jig pa'i pha rol tu phyin pas khur bor bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
khang thog tu phyin pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad chos thams cad kyi khyad par khong du chud cing / chos kyi khang steng du phyin par gyur cig/ ces sems bskyed do/ /
sbyin pa gtong ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad bdag gir bya ba med de/ yongs su 'dzin pa'i sems med cing bdag gi thams cad yongs su gtong bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
ma bral zhing 'grogs pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi mthar phyin te; 'du ba dang shin tu bral bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

If in palace rooms, They should wish that all beings Enter the sanctified state, Forever rid of defiled craving.
When putting on adornments, They should wish that all beings Give up phony decoration And reach the abode of truth.
When climbing up in balconies, They should wish that all beings Ascend the tower of truth And see through everything.
When they give something, They should wish that all beings Be able to relinquish all With hearts free of clinging.
When in gatherings or crowds, They should wish that all beings Let go of compounded things And attain to total knowledge.

btson ra la kha na ma tho bar mthong ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad gnas med pa la spyod cing gang du dga' bar 'dong bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
khyim nas khyim med par 'byung ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad sems bcings pa dang grol ba med cing / chags pa med de/ mi dgos pa dang bral bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
dge 'dun gyi ra ba'i mtshams 'da' ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad 'gal ba med pa'i chos dang ldan zhing mthun par 'gro ba mang po dang ldan par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
mkhan po dang slob dpon gyi drung du 'gro ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad chos la rtsom zhing cho ga la mkhas par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
rab tu 'byung bar gsol ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad bar chad med cing phyir mi ldog pa'i chos can du gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

If in danger and difficulty, They should wish that all beings Be free, Unhindered wherever they go.
When they give up home life, They should wish that all beings Have no hindrance in leaving home, And that their minds be liberated.
Entering a monastery They should wish that all beings Expound various principles Of noncontention.
Going to tutors and teachers, They should wish that all beings Skillfully serve their teachers And practice virtuous ways.
Seeking initiation, They should wish that all beings Reach the nonregressing state, Their minds without impediment

gos dkar po 'dor ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad sdig pa la brtson pa spangs te dge ba'i rtsa ba shin tu sbyangs par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
skra dang kha spu 'breg pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad shin tu mnyam par bzhag cing nyon mongs pa med par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
gos ngur smrig gon pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad drang srong chen po'i sems dang ldan zhing rnyog pa med par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
rab tu 'byung ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can rnams skye bo thams cad yongs su bskyang ba'i phyir de bzhin gshegs pa'i rab tu 'byung bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
sangs rgyas la skyabs su 'gro ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad dge ba la mos pa mngon par bskyed pas sangs rgyas kyi gdung mi 'chad pa'i don du brtson par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

Shedding lay clothing, They should wish that all beings Cultivate roots of goodness And abandon the yoke of transgressions.
When shaving off their hair, They should wish that all beings Forever divorce all afflictions And pass on to ultimate tranquility.
Putting on religious garb, They should wish that all beings Be undefiled in mind And fulfill the Way of the Great Sage.
When they formally leave home, They should wish that all beings Leave home with the Buddha And rescue one and all.
Taking refuge in the Buddha, They should wish that all beings Continue the lineage of Buddhas, Conceiving the unexcelled aspiration.

chos la skyabs su 'gro ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad chos kyi gter rab tu thob par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do; ;
dge 'dun la skyabs su 'gro ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad chags pa'i gnas dang bral zhing dge 'dun yongs su sdud par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
bslab pa'i tshig yang dag par len pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad tshul bzang po la yang dag par spyod cing / bslab pa thams cad shin tu bslab par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
slob dpon gyis bstan pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad log pa ma yin pa'i las la spyod cing tshul dang spyod yul phun sum tshogs par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
mkhan pos bstan pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad gnas med pa la yang dag par gzhol zhing mi skye ba'i ye shes kyi pha rol tu phyin par gyur cig/ ces sems bskyed do/ /

Taking refuge in the Teaching, They should wish that all beings Enter deeply into the scriptures And their wisdom be deep as the sea.
Taking refuge in the Community, They should wish that all beings Order the masses, All becoming free from obstruction.
When receiving the learners’ precepts, They should wish that all beings Learn self-control well And not do any wrong.
Receiving a mentor’s instruction, They should wish that all beings Bear themselves with dignity And that their actions be truthful.
Receiving a teacher’s guidance, They should wish that all beings Enter the knowledge of birthlessness And reach the state of independence.

bsnyen par rdzogs pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad chos thams cad kyi khyad par gyi pha rol tu phyin te thabs mkhas pa'i pha rol tu phyin par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
gtsug lag khang du 'gro ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad mi 'phrog pa'i chos can du gyur te bla na med pa'i gnas la rnam par spyod par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
stan 'ding ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad chos ji lta ba bzhin du mthong zhing legs par bkod pa'i chos can du gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
'dug pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad mi gnas pa'i sems kyis snying po byang chub la 'dug par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
skyil mo krung 'cha' ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad mi g.yo ba'i sa la dge ba'i rtsa ba shin tu brtan par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

Receiving the full set of precepts, They should wish that all beings Fulfill all means of liberation And master the supreme teaching.
When entering a hall, They should wish that all beings Ascend to the unexcelled sanctuary And rest there secure, unshakable.
When setting out a seat, They should wish that all beings Cause good principles to bloom And see their true character.
Sitting up straight, They should wish that all beings Sit on the seat of enlightenment, Their minds without attachment.
Sitting cross-legged, They should wish that all beings Have firm and strong roots of goodness And attain the state of immovability.

zhi gnas yongs su sbyor bar byed pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad ma lus pa'i mthar thug pa la brtson zhing zhi ba dang / dul ba la rab tu gzhol bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
lhag mthong yongs su sbyong bar byed pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad shin tu nyon mongs pa med pa'i chos can du gyur te/ chos yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du mthong bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
skyil mo krung 'jig pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad shin tu mnyam par gzhag cing 'du byed thams cad rang bzhin gyis 'jig pa rnam par mthong bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
rkang mthil gzhog pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad sems rnam par grol ba mi 'khrugs pa la rab tu gnas par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
rkang mthil 'degs pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad kha na ma tho ba med pa dang ldan pa thob ste 'khor ba'i rgya mtshor bying ba las 'thon par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

Cultivating concentration, They should wish that all beings Conquer their minds by concentration Ultimately, with no remainder.
When practicing contemplation, They should wish that all beings See truth as it is And be forever free of opposition and contention.
When uncrossing the legs, They should wish that all beings Observe that all acts and all things Return to dispersal and extinction.
When lowering the feet and resting, They should wish that all beings Attain liberation of mind, Resting at peace, unstirred.
When raising the legs, They should wish that all beings Leave the sea of birth and death And fulfill all good qualities.

smad g.yogs gyon pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad ngo tsha shes shing khrel yod pa bla na med pa dang ldan zhing dge ba'i rtsa ba shin tu brtan par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do; ;
ska rags 'ching ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad mi 'khrugs pa'i chos can du gyur te dge ba'i rtsa ba shin tu 'brel bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
bla gos gyon pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad chos thams cad kyi khyad par gyi pha rol tu phyin pa thob ste gong nas gong du dge ba'i rtsa ba thob par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
sbyar ma gyon pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad mi 'khrugs pa'i chos can du gyur te thabs dam pas mngon par bkab par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
so shing len pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad yongs su dag pa'i dngos po thob pa'i phyir dam pa'i chos rnam par dag pa thob par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

When putting on lower garments, They should wish that all beings Wear the foundations of goodness And have a sense of shame and conscience.
When putting on a belt, They should wish that all beings Bundle roots of goodness And not let them be lost.
When putting on an outer garment, They should wish that all beings Attain supreme bases of goodness And reach the Other Shore of the teaching.
Putting on monastic robes, They should wish that all beings Enter the foremost rank And attain imperturbability.
Taking a toothstick in hand, They should wish that all beings Attain the wonderful teaching And be ultimately pure.

so shing za ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad nyon mongs pa shin tu bcom ste sems dul zhing sems dag par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
dben par 'gro ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad 'dod chags dang / zhe sdang dang / gti mug spangs te sdig pa'i chos thams cad spangs par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
chu ngogs su 'gro ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos thams cad la shin tu byang bar gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
gtsang sbra'i las byed pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad shin tu dag pa'i dngos pos gtsang zhing nges pa dang ldan par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
lag pa 'khru ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad sangs rgyas kyi chos thams cad gzung zhing bcang ba'i phyir bkra shis kyi lag pa dang ldan par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

When chewing on the toothstick, They should wish that all beings Be harmonious and pure in mind, Biting through all afflictions.
When going to the toilet, They should wish that all beings Reject greed, hatred, and folly, And clean away sinful things.
When going to wash thereafter, They should wish that all beings Speedily go To the transmundane.
When washing off the body’s filth, They should wish that all beings Be pure and harmonious And ultimately without defilement.
When washing the hands with water, They should wish that all beings Have pure clean hands To receive and hold Buddha’s teaching.

ngo 'khru ba'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad shin tu nyon mongs pa dang bral zhing / chos thams cad kyi sgo rnam par dag pa thob par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
'khar ba len pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad mchod sbyin byas shing lam ston par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed de/ /
lhung bzed len pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad 'gro ba thams cad kyis mchod par 'os shing snod du gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /

When washing the face with water, They should wish that all beings Attain the pure teaching And be forever free from defilement.
Picking up a staff, They should wish that all beings Establish great works of charity And point out the road of truth.
Taking up a bowl, They should wish that all beings Perfect the vessel of truth And receive human and divine support.
spyod yul du mngon par zhugs pa'i tshe byang chub sems dpas sems can thams cad gnas med pa la yang dag par gzhol zhing sangs rgyas kyi spyod yul la mngon du phyogs par gyur cig /ces sems bskyed do/ /
